PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, will be absent today and that questions that would normally be directed to the leader should be directed to me.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes)-by leave-agreed to:
That paragraph 6 of Notice No. 2 standing in the name of the Leader of the Government be agreed to namely:
(6) Petitions-Procedure for Presentation: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the procedure for the presentation of Petitions be as follows:
(1) A Senator wishing to present a petition shall lodge it with the Clerk.

(2) The Clerk shall make an announcement in respect of petitions lodged with him, indicating in respect of each petition the Senator who presents it, the number of signatures, and the subject matter of the petition.
(3) Every petition so presented shall be deemed to have been received by the Senate unless a motion, moved forthwith, that a particular petition be not received, be agreed to.
(4) The terms of the petitions presented shall be printed in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Funding to Performing Arts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Federal Government funding to the performing arts through the Australia Council has declined since 1974 by 39% in real money terms.
2. Unless this funding is substantially increased in forthcoming federal budgets, many companies will be forced to cease operations and the performing arts will eventually wither and die.
3. A healthy and variegated performing arts scene is vital to any country that claims to be civilised.
4. The people of Queensland, particularly, value the performing arts and believe that without them, their lives would be significantly impoverished.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will substantially increase funding to the performing arts and will not allow the decline to continue at the alarming rate that has characterised the past seven years from 0 .12% of total government outlays in 1974-75 to 0.07% in 1981-82. And that the present single line appropriations are rescinded and the distribution of federal arts funding is left in the hands of the Australia Council.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BAUME; BOLKUS; BUTTON; CARRICK; CHIPP; JESSOP; LEWIS
PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 14 citizens), Bolkus (from 127 citizens), Button ( from 36 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 16 citizens), Chipp (from 31 citizens) , Jessop (from 59 citizens) and Lewis (from 63 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the film series produced by Film Australia in conjunction with the Family Planning Association for use in Australian schools ''Let's Talk About It'' is regarded in some Australian States as suitable only for in-service work with experienced teachers;
That its companion series ''Growing Up'' presents a one-sided advocacy of behaviour which is morally controversial;
That the films demonstrate serious deficiencies on educational as well as moral grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That action be taken to ensure that these films be withdrawn from use in Australian schools;
That no more funding be made available to Film Australia for production of sex- education films in conjunction with the Family Planning Association;
That an examination of the activities of the Family Planning Association in health and human relations studies in Australian schools be undertaken at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia's Heritage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Australian people have an irreplaceable heritage-built and natural- that is decaying before their eyes.
2. That the 1982-83 Federal Budget is the eighth in a row in which there has been no increase in funding for the preservation of Australia's heritage.

3. That the States and Territories were granted a total of only $2.2 million for an urgent program of works that is awaiting at least $20m to complete and that most of these projects will be in ruins before enough money is available.

4. That there are conservation projects in Queensland alone valued at tens of millions of dollars which have been postponed or abandoned due to lack of funding and that $3 million is needed immediately to complete restoration of properties owned by The National Trust of Queensland.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government approve an urgent supplementary grant of $800,000 for 1982-83, plus a forward commitment for a total allocation of $8 million in the 1983-84 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of accommodation and the provision of goods and services under Commonwealth jurisdiction and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 34 citizens) and by Grimes (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Office of Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth:

That citizens of Western Australia view with great alarm the removal of Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare sevices for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crichton-Browne (from 100 citizens), Durack (from 25 citizens) and Withers (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Stockman's Hall of Fame, Longreach
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australia has no national monument to commemorate the courage and the endeavours of our early pioneers and explorers.
2. In 1976, the National Council of the Stockman's Hall of Fame and Outback Heritage Centre was formed to co-ordinate efforts to build this monument.
3. A site was selected at Longreach in western Queensland in 1978 and a design by Sydney architect, Feiko Bouman, was approved two years later.

4. The early construction of a Hall of Fame at Longreach will be a fitting pioneer monument as well as a major tourist attraction, boosting the depressed rural economy of western Queensland and providing the employment that is so badly needed there to stem the population drift to the cities.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will invest whatever funding is necessary to enable the immediate construction of the Stockman's Hall of Fame and to enable researchers to collect the information, material and relics quickly, before they deteriorate or disappear forever, so that Australia can have a showcase for our national heritage and an inspiration to our national pride.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Benefits: Private Enterprise
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our concern that:
1. The Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act) and its administration is inadequate in providing retirement benefits for employees in private enterprise;
2. The Commissioner of Taxation (Commissioner) denies deductions necessary to index retirement pensions;
3. Deductions for the self-employed and employed are inadequate;
4. The Commissioner has exercised his discretion improperly by negating a choice the Act allows on investment in Government Securities;
5. The Commissioner's constant alterations to guidelines and lack of communication has created great uncertainty.
6. The Commissioner is acting arbitrarily, and without proper notice in restricting trustee's investments with employers.
7. The Commissioner seeks to apply new actuarial guidelines retrospectively to July 1982.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, take action to remedy these inadequacies and in particular we pray that action be taken:
(i) To ensure that the Commissioner exercises his discretion only with proper regard to legal principles;
(ii) To ensure that the Commissioner does not delegate to auditors part of his function of administering the Act;
(iii) To enact legislation allowing proper levels of retirement benefits to be provided;
(iv) To ensure that retirement benefits are regulated by a Department with a primarily social welfare function.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Request that the Minister of Communications make available a Public Broadcasting Category ''S'' licence for a Christian Radio Station for Perth.
The present broadcasting media in Perth does not include a christian radio station, and your petitioners wish to acknowledge the need for one.
During the period November 20, 1982 to November 26, 1982 Good News Broadcasters (operating under 6 GNB-FM, transmitting at a frequency of 106.5 MHz) have been broadcasting on a trial basis.

The programme which was broadcast has had a favourable response among your petitioners. They now call upon the Senate to persuade the Minister of Communications in granting the Good News Broadcasters a broadcasting licence so they can continue their ministry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Enrichment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Uranium enrichment is a chemical process which involves no nuclear reactions , no increase in radioactivity and no radioactive elements are produced.

2. The average level of radiation received by workers in U.S. enrichment plants over a five year period has been less than 50 milli-rem per year which is four times less than the occupant of a brick home.
3. A centrifuge enrichment plant would be clean, essentially noiseless and have little impact on the surrounding environment in which it was located.
4. The establishment of such a plant would generate significant export earnings for Australia.

5. The establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in South Australia would provide some 1,800 jobs during the construction and production stages and this would provide a significant boost to the South Australian economy.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to press for the establishment of a uranium plant in South Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate and Senators of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the recent reductions in Federal Government funding to the States for the provision of public health care have caused and will increasingly continue to cause, severe hardships to medical staff, nurses and other workers of the public health system of New South Wales.
That the aforementioned reductions in funding are severely jeopardising the safety of patients through reductions in medical, nursing and general hospital staff.
That the resulting staff reductions and increased workloads thereby imposed on remaining staff are producing severe stress and deteriorating morale among staff at all levels.
That the concept of ''the user pays'' and the phasing out of the universal health scheme are a grave injustice to low and middle income earners.
and respectfully call for:
Abolition of the concept of ''the user pays'' for health care;

Reintroduction of a universal health scheme; and urgent review and reassessment of funding to the states for health care with a view to relieving the deficiencies in the provision of health care services currently existing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Care: Aged Persons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia, respectfully showeth:
The Aged who are in need of nursing care in Nursing Homes, have the right to receive that care from properly trained nursing staff.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will ensure that adequate funds are provided which will enable the aged population of this country to receive the quality of nursing care that they deserve.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disabled Persons Attendant Care Allowance
PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth the need for the immediate introduction of an Attendant Care Allowance for Disabled people who need assistance with aspects of daily living.
This allowance will enable disabled people to live in the community.
It should be in the form of a benefit paid directly to the disabled person enabling him/her to employ and train the attendant of his/her own choice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chipp (from 191 citizens) and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 219 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Federal Police
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizen of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the members of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Federal Police Association seek a Senate inquiry into the Australian Federal Police concerning its functions and efficiency before assenting to any legislation concerning a new security force and the further wastage of public money.
Your petitioner humbly prays that Government will take measures to ensure than an enquiry is conducted.
And your petitioner as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Society
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we protest at the continual refusal of the Commonwealth Government to seek the opinion of the Australian people as to whether or not we should remain a homogenous European society, and that, against the advice of all public opinion polls it continues to dismantle the trouble free and cohesive structure of the Australian way of life; as it continues to promote and mislead the people on the alleged benefits of a multi-racial society.

That the Government seeks immediately to increase the percentage of Australians of British, Irish and other Caucasian background so that the traditions, heritage and way of life of our people shall not be destroyed.
That the position of Commissioner for Community Relations be phased out as the need diminishes with an increase in the content of British, Irish and Caucasian people in the Australian population.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the implementation of the recommendations of the Davidson Committee report into telecommunications services in Australia will have the effects of:

Increasing telephone rentals and call charges, particularly for rural and domestic subscribers and therefore putting telephone services beyond the economic reach of the isolated, frail and disabled who depend on the telephone for social contact;
Reducing service standards;
Increasing taxation by using Telecom services as a taxing medium;
Increasing unemployment in both Telecom and the Electronics Manufacturing Industry;
Destroying the security and sovereignty of telecommunications services in Australia;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government rejects the recommendations of the Davidson Report and preserves and develops Telecom as the sole provider of an integrated national Telecommunications system.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Archbishop, clergy and laymen of the Seventh Congress of the Australian and New Zealand Diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church (Abroad) assembled in Sydney on 27-29th December 1982, respectfully showeth that the Government of the USSR continues its blatant persecution of the Faithful, thus violating all international conventions and agreements.

Leaders of the Orthodox Faithful in the USSR (not the representatives of the officially sanctioned Patriarchate) and lay men and women who are active in organising religious discussion groups, or taking the Word of God to spiritually starved people, are being arrested, held without trial and/or sentenced to hard labour in concentration camps and subsequently exiled to remote areas of the country.

Progressively perfecting their methods of persecution and harassment Soviet authorities resort to confiscation of Bibles, Prayer Books and religious literature from believers languishing in concentration camps, and deny them visits by relatives, friends and clergy, in keeping with the long existing prohibition of Christian Mission in the USSR. They resort also to discrimination against relatives of religious prisoners whose families are often left destitute and denied any assistance from friends abroad. Parcels and letters are often returned undelivered, with no satisfactory explanation given by the Postal Authorities.
The most prominent of the imprisoned Orthodox believers are:
VLADIMIR OSIPOV
is still in a Mordovian camp (since 1974) and has been denied visits by relatives
Fr. GLEB YAKUNIN
ALEXANDER
OGORODNIKOV
VLADIMIR PORESH
have undertaken extensive hunger strikes in protest against confiscation of their copies of the Bible and Prayer Books
The latest victim of this inhuman persecution is the Editor/Compiler of the religious almanach 'Hope'
ZOYA KRAKHMALNIKOVA (arrested August 4, 1982) whose only crime is her belief in Our Lord Jesus Christ and her apostolic venture to make His Word known to her people.

We the undersigned, members of the Congress, humbly request that the Australian Government protest to the Government of the USSR in the strongest possible terms , against this senseless persecution of the Orthodox Faithful in the USSR, against harassment of their relatives.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

1. That the Queensland Government Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement rules the lives of Queensland's Aboriginal and Islander citizens in an authoritarian manner which resembles the agressive paternalism of the last century and, in fact, does little to nurture their advancement.

2. That Torres Strait Islanders are subjected to an official Government policy of 'integration' which has resulted in half the population drifting from their homelands to the mainland in search of employment.
3. That no serious attempt has ever been made by the Department to provide employment opportunities for the Islanders and establish industries in the Torres Strait and elsewhere.
4. That the Department has tolerated a 50-60 per cent level of venereal disease in the Torres Strait Islands for years.
5. That the cultural, social and economic position of black people in Queensland has actually been retarded under the command of the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will vote in approval of the establishment of a Senate Select Committee to inquire into the effects of the administration and other activities of the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement on the lives and well-being of the Aboriginal and Islander people under its control.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the Pensioner and Health Care Cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal Inquiry into South West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax Avoidance and Evasion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the continuing high level of tax avoidance and evasion is cause for grave concern for honest Australian taxpayers, and demands stringent and immediate action by the Commonwealth, noting in particular:
1. The latest estimate by the Australian Taxpayers' Association is that $7,000m a year is being lost in taxation revenue;
2. This figure can only continue to rise because of the timid approach by the Government in closing off tax loopholes; and
3. No effective inroads can be made until a comprehensive policy is adopted of levying tax from the date on which a scheme of tax avoidance is first used.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the minute from the Chief of Defence Force Staff, Sir Neville McNamara, to the Chief of the Air Staff, dated 12 April this year-one of the papers tabled by the Attorney-General yesterday-in which Sir Neville expressed his extreme concern that the decision to involve Royal Australian Air Force personnel in the Gordon below Franklin dispute was treated as a routine task. Sir Neville McNamara said that this demonstrated 'a lack of awareness of the political sensitivities and even deeper consequences of the use of defence assets in an issue such as the Franklin River Dam dispute'. I ask the Attorney: How is it that a non-political officer, albeit a very distinguished one, had such a clear perception of major constitutional issues, whereas the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth completely failed to understand them?

—All that the CDFS is doing in this memo is drawing attention to the obvious political sensitivity of the matter. I might add that he is doing so with the benefit of hindsight, given the way in which the operation was actually carried out. In drawing attention to the sensitivity of the matter, he is being critical in two directions: He is being critical downwards, of the operational officers under his command, for not alerting him of the nature of the proposed mission and seeking his formal approval for it, as indeed is required under the operative Defence Force guidelines, which I will again be happy to table should anyone ask me to do so at any later stage in this debate.
—I ask you now.

—Very well. For the benefit of Senator Durack and anyone else who may be interested I table a document entitled 'Defence Force Aid to the Civil Power-Situations Other Than Counter Terrorist Operations-Policy and Procedures'.
—Where are the Prime Minister's letters on this matter?
—The honourable senator can have whatever he likes.
—What about tabling the Prime Minister's letters?

—I did very nicely for you yesterday, Senator, by way of answering your interjection in respect of photographs. If we continue to answer your interjections in the course of Question Time you may end up with rather more questions during the year than you deserve.
—Order! I remind the Attorney-General that he is answering a question asked by Senator Durack.

—Indeed. The other criticism that the CDFS is implicitly making in this particular memorandum is of the failure of his political head to consult him in relation to this matter. That is a matter that the Minister for Defence is quite conscious of, as I am, and we readily acknowledge that mistakes were made in the way in which this whole operation was in fact implemented. I cannot really say much more than that. We fully accept ministerial responsibility for the way in which the operation was conducted-a classic demonstration as it was of Murphy's law.

—I preface my question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, by referring to the fact that yesterday the honourable senator, in answer to a question, described a meeting on Aboriginal health between the Minister and Mr Bird, the Queensland Minister responsible for Aboriginal and Island Affairs. I ask: In view of that discussion and the further evidence that is now available, will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs take immediate action to establish a royal commission to inquire into all aspects of the administration of Aboriginal affairs in Queensland by the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement in response to mounting evidence of the devastating effects of the genocidal policies of the present Queensland Government towards the Aboriginal and Islander population of that State?

—I share the concern expressed by Senator Jones in his question. As I indicated yesterday, the Government is acutely aware of the health problems of Aboriginal people in Queensland and the further evidence that has come to light in the past few days only increases our concern. The matter of establishing a royal commission is one for government decision. I will pass the honourable senator's suggestion on to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and obtain from him an early response as to his views on the feasibility and desirablility of establishing a royal commission into this very urgent matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney- General: In view of the continued and possibly exaggerated interest being taken in the use of Royal Australian Air Force facilities to photograph works being undertaken by the Tasmanian Government in the Franklin River area, does he agree that it would be wise now to employ private facilities to ensure that all necessary evidence is available to the court to establish continuing breaches of the laws of this country now in operation pursuant to the World Heritage (Western Tasmania Wilderness) Regulations, and that other red herrings should not be allowed to obscure the major issue-the full protection of the World Heritage area?

—I am indebted to Senator Missen for his clear-sighted and clear-headed appreciation of what the real issues are in this particular case. The real issues in this case have manifestly to do with the protection of this crucially significant part of the Australian and world environment. The Commonwealth Government is going about the business of protecting that crucial part of the national and international heritage in the best way that it possibly can. Senator Missen is right in saying that it is necessary that evidence continue to be accumulated as to what is happening in Tasmania. We are doing our best to do just that, in co-operation now with the Tasmanian Government following a communication offering such co-operation from Mr Gray during the week of the Summit. I can assure Senator Missen and the Senate that all necessary steps to accumulate evidence in support of the Commonwealth's position in this court case are being taken.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. My question of course refers specifically to the obtaining of evidence by commercial sources, not the RAAF. Has that method been considered?
—That is one of the options that have been considered and are continuing to be considered.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I ask: When will the Government be in a position to finalise the details of introducing computers into all schools? Will the Government give consideration to adopting a common system for all schools? Finally, can the Minister indicate whether a preference will be given to Australian manufactured computers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have placed the highest priority on advancing our program for introducing computer education into all schools. Our commitment takes this form: All government secondary schools and all needy non-government schools which have not yet been able to provide computer education for their students will be assisted over a three-year period to have programs operating, but we hope to have a result before the end of three years. In initiating this proposal I have already established within the Schools Commission a national committee which is investigating the kinds of matters which Senator Ray's question raises. I regard it of great importance that the systems that are introduced throughout Australian schools be compatible with each other. Apparently in the past there has been some ad hockery in the development of the curriculum associated with these courses.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the terms of reference of the national committee is that a common compatible system of computers be established throughout Australian schools, that there be national curriculum materials for software of the highest standard and that all schools have these curriculum materials available to them. To that end we have invited a number of computer curriculum experts on to the committee. We are also very aware of the need to promote Australian manufacturing wherever possible, and as my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology has pointed out many times, there is a potential within Australian manufacturing for the manufacture of computer hardware of this kind. One of the terms of reference of the committee is to look at the possibility of having the computer systems and the associated hardware as well as the software manufactured in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. In the light of the atomic test by the French Government on Mururoa Atoll, will the Minister advise whether it is true that the uranium mine at Ben Lomond in Queensland is 100 per cent owned by Minatome Australia Pty Ltd, a totally French company? Is the environmental impact statement on Ben Lomond presently being processed by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment on guidelines set up by the previous Liberal Government? Is this being done without taking into account public statements by the Government in recent days that it is reviewing its uranium mining policies? Can the Minister examine the situation to see what legislative or administrative action the Government can take? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Victorian Supreme Court decision, to which Senator Bolkus refers, is indeed a matter of very great interest to a very large number of people throughout this country who support Australian rules football, particularly in the honourable senator's own State, in my State and indeed I understand even in the State of Tasmania.
—And in Western Australia.

—I do not neglect Western Australia, in case there are any sensitivities there. Unfortunately, while I would be happy to help find some resolution to this problem, I regret that there does not really appear to be any way in which the Commonwealth can be of assistance, certainly not under the existing legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1979 the Federal Court of Australia held, in the case of Adamson v. the West Perth Football Club Incorporated, that the refusal of an Australian rules football club to grant a clearance to a professional footballer does not amount to a contravention of the Trade Practices Act because the relevant provision of that Act, section 45 (3), does not apply to contracts between football clubs and their players. The argument-if anyone is interested in the legal exotica surrounding this-is that what is involved here are contracts of service rather than contracts for services. The Trade Practices Act is concerned only with markets for goods or services.

It is for this reason that the proceedings which gave rise to the present problems for the Victorian Football League were proceedings in the Victorian Supreme Court rather than the Federal Court for restraint of trade under the common law. That, of course, is a State matter, not a Commonwealth one.

Since refusal to grant clearances to football players does not contravene the Trade Practices Act I am afraid there would not be any point in my referring, at the moment anyway, the matter to the Trade Practices Commission. Under those circumstances I will ask my Department to give the policy aspects of this matter some further consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he misled the Senate yesterday on the question of when the Prime Minister became aware of the second spy flight over the Gordon below Franklin Dam site. Does he deny that his joint statement with Mr Scholes on 14 April states that he first spoke to Mr Hawke about the Royal Australian Air Force involvement on the morning of Monday, 11 April, and that 'he told the Prime Minister that he had just received information from the Attorney-General's Department from which it appeared that there may in fact have been two flights the previous week and that he was seeking verification of this'? How does this tip-off to his leader square with yesterday's answer from him that: 'There is no question of the Prime Minister knowing about the two flights on Monday. He did not know about them, as I have indicated in subsequent public statements, until later in the week'? If Mr Hawke did not know about the flights on Monday, why did he issue orders on Monday morning putting an end to the whole business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that these distinctions are a little subtle for some honourable senators but there is a striking distinction that I seek to draw, and always have drawn, between a state of knowledge on the one hand and a state of belief as to the possibility on the other. The situation is that on the Monday morning, as I explained in answer to someone else earlier, I was in a state of belief as to the possibility of there having been an F111 flight, as a result of Mr Glare's memorandum to which I referred. Mr Glare knew that an F111 had been airborne; he had been told as much on Friday. But that aircraft was airborne in the first instance as part of a mission that took it over oil rigs in Bass Strait and over the Australian Defence Force Academy in Canberra and which also involved some photographic training runs in the Sydney-Gosford area. It was only in the last ten minutes of the flight that it diverted down, we now know, and took a picture of the Gordon below Franklin Dam.

ANSWER.PARA: On Monday morning Mr Glare was not in a state of knowledge as to whether the F111 had in fact gone on to fly over Tasmania. He had not been told in any detail about that. I said: 'For God's sake, will you verify that so that we know what is going on and what did go on?' He then went about the task of verification but that verification did not come to me in a form which amounted to knowledge on my part until, as I have continually said, Tuesday afternoon. As I said in the joint Press statement with the Minister for Defence, what happened on the Monday morning so far as the Prime Minister is concerned is that when I spoke to him on the Monday morning during the tea break in the National Economic Summit Conference I said, in the course of a conversation which concentrated more on questions of basic principle than on matters of precise detail: 'It seems that there may in fact have been two flights but I do not have verification of that. I am seeking it'.

That really puts the situation in a nutshell. I did not have any further conversation with the Prime Minister about this matter, since quite properly he was preoccupied with other matters in the other chamber, until later in the week when the news emerged publicly of the existence of the F111 flight. There is no inconsistency in any of the positions I have taken, either publicly or privately , in explaining the course of events at any stage and certainly there has been no question of misleading the Parliament.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF ALL FORMS OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In view of a biased and ill-informed campaign by the League of Rights and the organisation known as Women Who Want to be Women against the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, can the Attorney- General please explain the reasons for and the implications of ratification of this important Convention, action which, I might say, is supported by all reputable established Australian women's organisations? Is there any truth at all in the assertions of drastic impositions upon Australian society such as the elimination of gender by law or at least the conscription of all 18-year-old girls into the defence forces?

—There is no foundation for any of the wilder assertions that have been made and continue to be made about the effect of sex discrimination conventions, treaties and domestic legislation of this kind. Nor is it even proposed that there be obligatory unisex toilets in the future as the result of any such changes to the law. The Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women was signed by Australia on 17 July 1980. Its ratification has been the subject of a fairly endless round of consultations and meetings between the Commonwealth and State Ministers over the last three years, a process which is now likely to be rather dramatically cut short following the change of government at Commonwealth level because the Commonwealth indicated clearly through me at a recent meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General that it proposes to move ahead very quickly to the ratification of that Convention and to accompany that ratification with the absolute minimum of reservations and declarations. There may need to be one or two such reservations or declarations, including one in relation to combat duty in the armed forces, which has been the subject of concern not only from the groups to whom the honourable senator referred but also from others in the community. But the treaty, when ratified, will lay a firm foundation for two things: Firstly, Australia's stance and the credibility of Australia's stance in the international community as a country committed fully to the removal of all forms of discrimination against women; and, secondly, of course, effective national legislation within Australia which will enable a concerted and vigorous attack to be made on sex discrimination, including in those jurisdictions where no willingness hitherto has been demonstrated to mount such an attack.

Parameters are laid down in the electoral law and the Constitution within which certain things have to occur. But the actual precise timing within those parameters is a matter for the Government to determine. There is no question but that the responsibility lies squarely in the lap of the former Prime Minister for that particular cynical exploitation of the opportunities available to him under the electoral law to disenfranchise those Australians. That is a situation that will not be allowed to continue under any circumstances in the future. There are two ways in which we will be ensuring that that is so. One is by appropriate amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, I understand, although that is still the subject of further obvious consideration by the Ministers in the Cabinet, but more particularly by the concept of a fixed term parliament. If we can succeed in having that concept endorsed by the Australian people as now seems likely, there will, of course, be a situation prevailing in the future where, except for the most exceptional circumstances, everybody will know well and truly in advance when elections are scheduled and be able to enrol accordingly. That will, of course, still solve the problems only so far as general elections are concerned; there will be problems so far as by-elections are concerned unless the electoral law is changed. But that is certainly the intention of the present Government to deal with the law in that way.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will he tell us when the Prime Minister intends to reply to the letter from the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, which was handed to him 11 days ago and which protested about the use of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft to photograph progress on the Gordon below Franklin Dam site? Despite all that has been said and written since then, why has the Prime Minister not had the courtesy to acknowledge Mr Gray's concern in any way or does the Prime Minister perhaps share the view expressed by the Attorney-General yesterday that Tasmanian political representatives appear as though they come from another planet? Is not the Deputy Leader himself a Tasmanian political representative?
—I will ignore the feeble attempts at political rhetoric in that question and will seek from the Prime Minister as soon as possible the information that the honourable senator requires.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONSTITUTIONAL QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the constitutional qualifications of members of parliament. Has the Government yet had the opportunity to decide whether it will facilitate the implementation of some of the recommendations in this report? In particular, can the Attorney- General see any changes being made in the near future which will remove the necessity for a Commonwealth or State public servant to resign in order to contest a Senate or House of Representatives election?

—The Government has not yet given consideration to that report of the Senate committee, although it appreciates the unfairness that the present state of the law, both under the Constitution and under the Commonwealth Electoral Act, is in fact working. The matter of this report and the constitutional changes that may be necessary if the situation is to be fully corrected will be dealt with by the Constitutional Convention in Adelaide next week, although the likely outcome of that debate will simply be a reference of the matter to a committee. As a result it cannot be expected that there will be any immediate move towards constitutional amendment on that front. Nonetheless a number of matters are capable of being remedied by legislation, primarily Commonwealth legislation. That is something to which I hope the Government will give very urgent attention because of the injustices that are capable of being worked in this respect.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs inform the Senate of details of the proposed inquiry into Aboriginal land rights announced recently by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? In particular, can the Minister outline the objectives of the inquiry and the groups and persons which it is intended to involve? Further, will the Minister inform the House what proposals, if any, there are to introduce uniform legislation early next year and whether that legislation will be introduced despite opposition from any State or territorial government? Finally, will the Government table the report upon its completion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give Senator Kilgariff the information I have but I think what he is seeking is fairly detailed and that most of his question will have to be referred to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced on 18 April an inquiry into the provisions and operations of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Such an inquiry is contemplated in terms of section 61 (2) of the Act and is confined to the provision of a report in respect of the operations of the Act. The Minister is consulting with my colleague the Attorney-General about the possibility of the former Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, being available to prepare such a report. I will refer the other matters that Senator Kilgariff raised to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding. When we have fuller information as to the Minister's intentions in this matter I will inform Senator Kilgariff and the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: I should point out that the necessity for such an inquiry has come about because of the negligence and ineptitude of the previous Government in its handling of this matter. For some time there have been some problems associated with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, particularly the failure of the Act to cover the circumstances of Aboriginal people living on excisions; that is, small packets of land on pastoral properties in the Northern Territory. Their needs are not being met. That is one aspect of the Act which in my view and, I believe, in the view of the Government, needs amendment. There are other problems relating to the conduct of pastoral properties which become Aboriginal land and those matters need to be dealt with too. Undoubtedly, the behaviour of the previous Federal Government in this matter, where it continued to put off attending to the serious anomalies in the Act and continued to allow itself to be persuaded by the Northern Territory Government that the Act really ought not to be proceeded with, and that its positive features ought to be reduced, has led to a situation where an inquiry is necessary. When I am able to get the kind of detailed information that Senator Kilgariff sought I will let him and the Senate have it.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Durack proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The total ineptitude of the Attorney-General in the Tasmanian spy planes fiasco, his failure to explain his actions in any credible sense and his utmost reluctance to admit the error of his ways.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the incredible events which were slowly unfolded last week, having had to be dragged out of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) over several days, in the light of the further revelations that emerged in the Senate yesterday and today and particularly because of information contained in documents which have been tabled, it seemed to me that it was a matter of the utmost public importance and , indeed, of urgency that the Senate should discuss the total ineptitude of this Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, in the Tasmanian spy planes fiasco, his failure to explain his actions in any believable way and his utmost reluctance to admit the errors of his ways, although his defence has been extraordinary. He now seems to be pleading guilty in some qualified way, in some new form of criminal defence which Senator Evans perhaps has dreamt up or which he may wish to pursue in other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, Senator Evans has never enjoyed the same reputation in this chamber as he seems to enjoy in the Press Gallery, in the Law Reform Commission and among some circles of undergraduates. But I think even honourable senators will have been staggered by the series of political stupidities and schoolboy evasions in which he has recently indulged. It would really be a temptation just to laugh off the matter as Senator Evans tried to laugh it off with his famous streaker's defence-the throw away line he used the other day. It is a great temptation to laugh it all off. It is a great temptation simply to put it down to the zeal of the first few weeks of office and to say that the zeal and power have gone to his head.

In fact, the matter is of the utmost importance because it reaches absolutely the depths of our Constitution. It simply is not good enough for an Attorney- General to behave in this way, to defend himself in this way and to be so reluctant to give the nation the full truth about his actions and those of the people who were associated with him in this exercise. This man is the chief legal adviser of the Government, a man who has the ministerial responsibility for the maintenance of law and justice on behalf of the Commonwealth and a man whose obligation it is to uphold the Constitution. Although Senator Evans may be upset about this and would prefer the situation to be otherwise, that Constitution happens to be a federal Constitution. It happens to embrace six States which have very clear rights.

An even more fundamental constitutional issue is here at stake. That is the issue which, indeed, was perceived immediately by the Chief of Defence Force Staff, Sir Neville McNamara, in the minute to which I referred in Question Time and which Senator Evans tried to divert into another aspect. I suggest that all honourable senators study what Sir Neville said. It does clearly show the situation. We should be thankful that we have a Chief of Defence Force Staff who does understand these fundamental questions about the role of the military power in a democracy, a role about which, as I have said, Senator Evans seems to be confused.

I think that is the fundamental problem with which we are faced by Senator Evans's actions- he just does not seem to understand this fundamental role of the military power and its relationship to the civil power, the Parliament and the people. That goes to the very heart of our democratic principles. It has been very slowly developed through our Westminster system of government. I know that Senator Evans is not so impressed with that Westminster system but I think that even on this subject-if he really understood it-he would acknowledge its importance.

Here is a man who is very keen on law reform. He tells the world that he is going to be a great law reformer, but before he starts reforming it I think he should take a crash course in what the law is. He is supposed to be a great constitutional lawyer, in his own estimate and perhaps in the estimate of a few of his undergraduate students, but I think he needs to do a fundamental study of constitutional priniciples, not just of this particular constitution but of the constitutional principles of our democratic system. As I have said, the subordinate role of military power is absolutely fundamental to our democracy. Senator Evans is also going to introduce a Bill of Rights. We have heard a lot from him about rights, Bills of rights and everything he is going to do about them. I refer Senator Evans and the Senate to the Bill of Rights of 1688-I am sure he must have read it and he must remember it-which contains these words:
The raising or keeping of a standing army within the Kingdom in time of peace, unless it be with the consent of Parliament, is against the law.

That is a statement of that fundamental principle. From 1713 until 1955-in 1879 there was a small change-the House of Commons annually passed an Army Act to approve a standing army for one year only. It had to be passed every year. That puts the whole subject in a nutshell. Since 1955 the House of Commons has not reneged on that principle but it now provides the funds by annual appropriations , the same as we do. The long tradition of passing that annual Army Act was of vital importance in highlighting that subordinate role of military power to the civil power.

Senator Evans was wrong in his actions in the week after Easter in requesting these matters in the way in which he did. No formal approval was obtained by the Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, nor was there ever any formal direction from the Chief of Defence Force Staff or the Chief of the Air Staff authorising the use of this aircraft. No formal approval was given-not for some re-routing of an ordinary operational activity, as Senator Evans tried to suggest on AM-for a special flight by an F111 in secret. Senator Evans objected yesterday to the reference to spy flights. According to the documents one of the first directions to the Mirage squadron was that there was to be photography to show the extent of the work carried out at the dam site. It stated: 'Aircraft should attract as little attention as possible'.

The deputy secretary, Mr Glare, tells us that it was done so as to not alarm the Tasmanians. And Senator Evans says it was not a spy flight! What a pathetic defence. Everybody knows it was a spy flight. Everybody is rightly calling it a spy flight and Senator Evans had better accept the fact that it was. His pathetic defence is: 'Of course it was not, because if the photographs had been all right and if they had been needed they would have been produced in court'. But what if they had not been all right, as indeed was the case with the Mirage photos? What if they had not been needed in court? No one would have known about the flight. He was desperately anxious that it should all be done at 30,000 feet by an F111.

Mr President, let me give you a classic example of the ineptitude of Senator Evans or of those who were assisting him in this exercise. We accept his word as to the conversation with Mr Scholes, although I think Mr Scholes should be asked some questions about it in another place at another time, and no doubt that will be done. For the time being let us accept Senator Gareth Evans's version. First of all he had to be advised to request information. It is a very interesting note of 11 April from Mr Glare. He said that he attended a conference with the Attorney, apparently on 5 April, and relayed the information to the Attorney- General in the presence of the Secretary to the Department, Mr Brazil. That was the information he had obtained about the F111 and its ability to fly at 30,000 feet, to take photographs and so on. Mr Glare went on to say:
The Attorney-General inquired whether it would be necessary to consult the Minister for Defence.

I ask you! Here is a request for a spy flight over a State, concerning proceedings against a State; yet the Attorney-General asked Mr Glare, his deputy secretary, whether it was necessary to consult the Minister for Defence. Mr Glare said 'I thought it was necessary', and that is how the Attorney-General came to speak to the Minister for Defence. It was on the advice of a deputy secretary to his Department. He does not even have sufficient political nous to understand what is required.

The Attorney-General told us about speaking to the Minister for Defence. The first glimmer of political sanity was exhibited by Mr Scholes. The first thing Mr Scholes told the Attorney was: 'Put that in writing'. He had a bit of sense; we will find out how much on another occasion. The Attorney then had a letter prepared for him, I suppose again by one of his departmental officers, which was signed the next day, 6 April. The first spy flight took place as a result of Mr Glare's requests-he was executor for Senator Evans in all of these exercises-on Thursday, the 7th. The F111 was airborne, as Mr Glare tells us, at about 11.15 on Friday, the 8th. Senator Evans's letter of the 6th did not reach the office of the Minister for Defence until the 8th, after the spy flights had occurred. Are we not justified in talking about ineptitude? Mr Scholes never put in train the proper authorisations-which, of course, is so clearly revealed by Sir Neville McNamara.

I now come to the ways in which Senator Evans tried to explain the matter away. His chief executor in this operation, Mr Glare, knew the facts on Friday, 8 April. Today we heard Senator Evans's pathetic efforts to explain the minute away. If Mr Glare knew that the F111-the aircraft that had been requested-was airborne at 11.15, is anybody suggesting that it was not airborne to carry out the flight? Was Mr Glare in any real doubt? Mr Glare, or somebody in the Attorney-General's Department, apparently told Senator Evans on Monday morning about the flight. It would have been an extraordinary delay if there had been doubt but officers had not found out about the flight even by Monday morning.

The fat was well and truly in the fire on Monday morning because news about the flight had gone out. The Press was asking questions. I believe Senator Evans, although I did not hear him, said something about the matter on Sunday night. He certainly had plenty to say on AM on Monday morning. He issued a statement later that day. He was really under pressure. By that stage he had been reprimanded by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about it. His Prime Minister had told him that it was not on. I would love to have a record of the conversation between the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General. That would really be worth having. I think it might be worth seeking some more information about that matter, because there seem to be some doubts about what was said that morning. Senator Evans, however, says he did not get confirmation of the whole truth until Tuesday afternoon, four days after Mr Glare knew the facts.

Is he really going to blame Mr Glare? Is he going to say Mr Glare did not do his job? Of course, we know Senator Evans's views on ministerial responsibility: If Mr Glare failed so dismally in such a vital matter, of course the Attorney- General would accept responsibility and it would be a resigning matter. That is Senator Evans's own evaluation. We might hear some more about that too from the Attorney-General. We might have some more to say about it ourselves at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps he has changed his views.

—Yes, there seem to have been some remarkable changes in him in many ways since he got into government. On Tuesday afternoon, when he knew the full facts, did he tell anyone what they were? He had been talking his head off, as he usually does, on Sunday and Monday and he knew the full facts on Tuesday. The fat was in the fire again on Wednesday. Of course, when he had not said anything about the F111 flights, somebody tipped off the Press about the second flight. That was natural enough. The Press were all agog again on Wednesday. We waited all day Thursday-I was waiting all day Thursday-to hear what Senator Evans had to say. It was not until very late on Thursday afternoon that we had the statement from Senator Evans and Mr Scholes.

SPEECH.PARA: What a pathetic exercise in total ineptitude, a schoolboy effort at evasion in giving us the whole truth. I do not want to say more about Senator Evans's pathetic efforts at his defence which he made at the Press Club and in the Senate. Here we have a sorry story of fumbling and bumbling; but I think there ought to be a bit of tumbling as well. Here we have an Attorney-General who, within five weeks of taking office, has been publicly reprimanded, humiliated by his Prime Minister. We have seen his pathetic performance in the Senate. I would be reluctant to lose Senator Evans as Attorney-General. As far as the Opposition is concerned, I think he will be a wonderful source of embarrassment to the Government. Why should the Opposition worry about that? However, I think that really on his performance and past statements, he ought to seriously consider-or perhaps the Prime Minister should consider-whether the Government can continue to afford having Senator Evans as its Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see Senator Durack settling so quickly and cheerfully into the role of Opposition gadfly, a role that on the strength of his performance today he is going to be playing in Opposition for some considerable time yet. Clearly, Senator Durack is discovering, as I have been discovering over the last couple of weeks, that when it comes to criticism it is rather more blessed to give than to receive. I acknowledge, of course, that there are grounds for criticising me and my performance in this matter. I acknowledge that the use of the Mirage aircraft, for which I have to take some ministerial responsibility-much as it hurts-was extraordinarily provocative and justified the description 'silly and provocative ' that various people were giving to it at the time. I also acknowledge that the use of military aircraft flying at any height, whether at 200 or 30,000 feet, did involve a very considerable degree of political unwisdom given the obvious volatility and sensitivity of the Tasmanian dam situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Those criticisms were, however, quite clearly and effectively conveyed to me by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on Monday morning. Indeed, I think the toe-cutter would have been proud of the Prime Minister on that occasion. I do not really need any extra assistance of the kind I have received this morning from Senator Durack to make me appreciate the force of those criticisms. In terms of the matter of public importance before us this morning, referring as it does to ineptitude, while I am naturally reluctant to concede or give any ground on the score of ineptitude, I am obliged to concede that my actions in the respects that I have identified did possibly lack something in eptitude. However, I do not believe that there are any grounds for the other criticisms that are made in the terms of the matter of public importance. The point that is made about my alleged utmost reluctance to admit the error of my ways is, I believe, utterly unfounded. I think it is fair to say that I have eaten enough humble pie on this matter in the last couple of weeks to keep Four 'n Twenty in business for a year .

But the criticisms go further than that. One criticism was of my failure to explain in any credible sense what we were about. As to the matter of explanation, I really find it quite extraordinary on a reading of the media coverage of what happened in the Senate yesterday-indeed, on consideration of the way in which this matter has been approached by Opposition spokesmen and honourable senators today-that the fact that it was I, the Attorney-General, who tabled yesterday all the documents relating to the RAAF photographic survey has been totally overlooked. The documents were tabled at the first available parliamentary opportunity-the first opportunity on the first day of sitting of the new Parliament. They were not tabled in any way reluctantly, but out of a genuine commitment, which I endeavoured to articulate in this place yesterday, to the principles of freedom of information.

I believe it is entirely proper and appropriate when an incident of this kind occurs in which actions need to be explained that all the documentation and the sequence of events-muddled as they are undoubtedly were, as is revealed in the documents-should be put in the public record. What it then comes down to is not a failure to explain, because there has been ample explanation of what happened; it is the failure or alleged failure on my part to explain credibly just how it is that I came to embark upon what is described in the matter of public importance as 'this adventure'.

I think it is fair that I be given another opportunity, as I sought to do yesterday, to put briefly on the record not a defence of my actions but rather what I have described as further and better particulars which explain why I acted as I did. In legal terms, I would describe it as a plea of mitigation that at least there be some understanding of what the motivation and the circumstances were at the time that the relevant decision was made a couple of weeks ago. In that respect, the four points I made yesterday deserve a degree of repetition.

There were four factors very clearly in my mind on that Wednesday a fortnight ago when I requested that the photographic survey be undertaken. The first consideration in my mind was the necessity to monitor the situation on the ground in the South West wilderness area to determine whether what was happening there was, in fact, causing irreparable damage to the environment. The Government made a clear commitment during the election campaign-overwhelmingly endorsed by the great majority of Australians except those in Tasmania, as I readily acknowledge-to protect this area. We had clearly intimated and articulated our course of action; clearly, that won the support of a great majority of Australians. We regarded ourselves, as we do now, as having a very clear obligation to this nation as a whole and, indeed, to the international community to protect this area from wanton depredation. That involves the taking of a number of steps, not only the promulgation of regulations now to be supplemented by the further legislation introduced last night, but also the taking of the first available opportunity to institute legal proceedings to enforce those regulations. A further legal step potentially available to us was the seeking of an interim injunction to hold the situation intact until such time as the full scale legal proceedings for a permanent injunction could be brought to hearing and determination. Against that background it was perceived to be necessary-I think that perception will be understood-to maintain a fairly close scrutiny of what was happening to ensure that the situation did not get completely out of hand. Given the enthusiasm with which Mr Gray and his Government have been pursuing the devastation of the environment down there, that was a very real concern on our part. That was the first consideration-the need to monitor the situation as best we could.

The second consideration which we had very much to the forefront of our minds concerned the extraordinary series of statements made by Mr Gray over the preceding days and weeks. The statements indicated that physical confrontation and violence were very far from being ruled out from the array of tactics that Mr Gray had in mind to defend what he is claiming to be the interests of the States. The weekend preceding the RAAF flights, statements by Mr Gray were universally reported in the nation's Press. They were to the effect that if anyone came physically on to the dam site or the area occupied by the Hydro- Electric Commission, that person would be subjected to arrest. That stricture extended to Australian Federal Police officers engaged in the enforcement of Commonwealth law.

I would have thought, in terms of an understanding by a political figure of the legal obligations and constraints of one's office, that that ranks as one of the most despicable demonstrations on the part of a senior political figure of a failure to appreciate the legal ground rules within which this country and its component parts operate. It is one of the most despicable such illustrations in the history of this country. Faced as we were with that kind of extravagant language and threats from Mr Gray, obviously we had very much in our minds that any such monitoring of the situation on the ground would be better coped with by means other than those involving the physical presence in the area of personnel, whether they be members of the Australian Federal Police or anyone else. We were naturally led, as a result of that train of reasoning, to contemplate some form of aerial reconnaissance or aerial photographic survey.

The next consideration we had in mind-I had it very much in mind in deciding as I did to make this request to the Defence Department-was the desire, given the Gray arguments, to act in such a way that there would be no overt provocation, certainly no confrontation. I have already mentioned the fact that we wanted no confrontation, but we were equally concerned that there be no provocation. There was a very inflammatory situation prevailing in Tasmania. Spokesmen from my own party down there were using language which indicated the very profound concern on the part of Tasmanians generally that the situation could very well escalate if there were perceived to be very overtly provocative action by the Commonwealth. That in turn suggested that the means employed to monitor the situation to gather evidence of the kind I have been mentioning should be means that did not involve overt provocation and did not involve, to use the language of my departmental officer, alarm to people on the ground and produce the result of stirring up a potentially very inflammatory situation.

Bearing all those factors in mind, the fourth consideration became one involving the best way of satisfying all those goals, simultaneously getting high quality aerial survey photographic evidence that could be useful in establishing precisely what was happening and getting that evidence in a quality form and by a means which did not involve provocation or inflammation of the situation. The conclusion I was led to-I accept full responsibility for it-was that military aircraft with the appropriate highly sophisticated photographic equipment available to them were the best means. I satisfied myself that there was no question as to the legality of the use of the aircraft for these purposes . I make it clear that there was no question as to the illegality. In fact, it was perfectly legal and perfectly routine for such requests for defence aid to the civil power in situations of this kind to be made. Having established all those things, I acted accordingly, made the oral request to the Defence Minister , supplemented it with the written request and then, of course, knew no more about what had occurred until the story broke in the Press on Sunday.

A little more perhaps ought to be said about the question of the routine character of these flights and the legality of the way in which they were, in fact, conducted. There has been a really quite deliberate attempt on the part of the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack, to fudge the question of legality. In one sentence he is talking about constitutional law, in a second sentence about constitutional principle and in a third sentence about the proper procedures of consultation and so on. The whole thing is just a dreadful muddle in Senator Durack's mind. The reality of the matter is that the law on this issue is perfectly clear and the practice that has prevailed in this area is perfectly clear. For example, it was articulated by none other than the former Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, in answer to Question No. 335, recorded in Hansard at page 1254 on 7 April 1978. In the course of a long answer about the formal procedures that are required enabling the regular forces to be called out in cases of, firstly, aid to the civil community for anti-terrorist activities and, secondly, natural disasters, Mr Killen gave a perfectly accurate account of what the procedures were. I am happy to table this answer in due course to add to the pile of documents which have been waded through by the bush and Philadelphia lawyers on the other side. The particular passage that is most relevant is the one which concludes his answer. It states:

Where the likelihood of the Defence Force members being involved in the use of force does not exist, for example, to deal with a natural disaster, or to carry out a bomb disposal task under such circumstances, there is no requirement for call out.
