The Defence Force acts only in response to requests from the responsible civil authorities in accordance with guidelines and instructions endorsed by the Minister for Defence.

The guidelines and instructions he is, no doubt, referring to in that answer, are the guidelines which I have already tabled in this place today which set out in very elaborate detail and in a form which it is inappropriate for me to try to read into the record at this stage, but-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read out paragraph 20 of them?
—Read out paragraph 14.
—I will read out anything honourable senators would like me to read out if I have time to do it. But-let me just read out some of the relevant paragraphs. Paragraph 3 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the definition of 'aid to the civil power' is:
'Defence Force aid to the Commonwealth and/or State Governments and their civil authorities in their performance of law enforcement tasks.'
This document deals with situations other than counter-terrorist operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paragraph 14.
—Paragraph 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Defence Force providing aid to the civil power are to remain under Defence Force command, and the commander of the Defence Force element-
Not the Chief of Defence Force Staff but the Defence force element-
is to act in accordance with the directions given by the Minister for Defence and subsequently issued through command channels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was the direction from the Minister for Defence?
—The directions from the Minister for Defence, as I understand it, are standing directions applicable in these circumstances which we are in fact reading from now. The paragraph continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In executing the directions given by the Minister, the commander of the Defence Force element is to act in response to approaches from and in co-ordination with the appropriate civil authorities, recognizing that he remains accountable for his actions.

It is simply a matter of how one construes that paragraph and whether it applies in general terms or whether it applies to each particular instance. If one looks at the key paragraphs governing the provision of aid in no force situations, the situation is made perfectly clear. Paragraph 17 states:
Where there is no likelihood that Defence Force personnel will be required to use force, personnel and equipment may be used without 'call out' under the following conditions:
Those conditions are set out in paragraphs a, b and c. Paragraph a states:
The approach is made by a Police Commissioner, his delegate or an authority superior to them, through established State and Commonwealth channels. . .

There is a further reference to aid being approved by the Chief of Defence Force Staff. It is clear that there was no such approval by the CDFS in this case. That has been readily and cheerfully acknowledged. There is no reference in paragraph 17, paragraph 18 or paragraph 20 which relates to an urgent request- this was perceived by the military as an urgent request, rather wrongly in fact- to specific ministerial approval. In any event, ministerial approval was given; there was simply a failure of communication down the line. Everyone has been playing a game of pass the parcel in this instance except the two Ministers concerned who fully and cheerfully accept, as we are obliged to do-we did not see it very often during the tenure of the last Government-responsibility for what was obviously a series of failures of communication both down and back up the line until after the event.

TALK.START.PARA: —What followed the acceptance of responsibility?
—It is our responsibility. We accept it. We made that perfectly clear.
—What was the theory of ministerial responsibility you propounded on Costigan?

—In a matter of profound seriousness and gravity I cannot remember the exact formula I employed but it was to the effect that the Minister in question was obliged to resign. This is not alleged by anyone to be a matter of such gravity. It involved neither a breach of the law nor any fundamental breach of propriety, nor does it involve any breach of the explicit language of the directions under which the Defence Force operates in these particular matters. There is no doubt about the formal legality of what happened, there is no doubt about the technical appropriateness of what happened and there is no doubt about the legitimacy of what occurred in terms of its consistency with the ordinary operational and training activities of the Royal Australian Air Force. The particular flight of the F111 that I mentioned before in fact, occurred in the context of an additional leg-a rerouting, if one likes to call it that-of a flight which involved, as I said in Question Time, surveillance of oil rigs in Bass Strait, the Defence Force Academy site in Canberra and some training photographs of the Sydney-Gosford area. It was in the context of a slight addition to that particular flight.

SPEECH.PARA: There are arguments about the common political sense of what occurred. I have conceded as much as any reasonable person, let alone any reasonable politician, could be obliged to concede in these circumstances. I think the terms of the matter of public importance are misconceived in the way in which it is expressed and the force, vigour, diversity and extent of the criticism that is implied. Some criticism is appropriate. The force of that criticism has been openly acknowledged. An explanation has been given fully and frankly of everything that occurred. I really believe it is appropriate that the Opposition devote its time from now on to pursuing matters of rather more fundamental importance to the future of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put aside Senator Evans's complete immaturity in dreaming up this action against my State in the first place. Instead, I will deal with the legality of those flights. I will read a short section from a memo written about this incident by Air Marshal McNamara, who is Chief of Defence Force Staff. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in particular I am extremely concerned that the matter appears to have been handled as a routine task within your Directorate of Operations and authorization given without your or my knowledge. At the very least this action demonstrates a lack of awareness of the political sensitivities and even deeper consequences of the use of Defence Force assets in an issue such as the Franklin River Dam.

What are those deeper consequences that the Chief of Defence Force Staff is hinting at? Senator Evans has not answered that question. The Chief of Defence Force Staff thought it was so highly provocative that it could lead to Australian confronting Australian. He considered it of such great concern that he stated:
I find it equally disturbing that in such a matter I was not given the opportunity to provide timely advice to the Minister in terms of my responsibilities as his principal military adviser.
He made it very clear that he would have advised the Minister not to go that way .

The attack on the Premier of my State, as can be seen by the statements that have been put out by the Chief of Defence Force Staff, has certainly not been substantiated. Senator Gareth Evans has only indicated his dislike of the Premier and his arrogant assumption that he is the one with the power to use the Defence Force and will use it over the will of the Premier and of my State-

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us an example of circumstances in which you think it could be used.

—I would not interject if I were you; you are in enough trouble back home as it is; I would keep very quiet. Equally, I would give a warning to Senator Grimes and to Senator Tate. Senator Hearn is not even in the chamber. I turn now to the circumstances under which permission was given by the Minister for Defence and the legality or otherwise of the flights. First, I refer to the misinformation involved. Very clearly, the Minister stated in his letter of 12 April:

SPEECH.PARA: I . . . was advised that it was a re-routed training flight-
He gave permission when he was advised that it was just a re-routed training flight.

Next I come to the timing of the Attorney-General seeking permission from the Minister for Defence. I would be very grateful if the Attorney-General could answer as to the times and dates to which I shall refer. Again, in regard to the misinformation aspect, Mr Scholes was advised that the flight had been re-routed . Compare that with the urgency expressed to Group Captain Waterfield, who was told that it must happen and must happen very quickly. He said he was told that the task was urgent and should be completed before the court case, which he anticipated would be the next day. That does not lead me to believe that it was just a re-routed training flight. It was secret. As Senator Durack has already stated, the task message in regard to the flight indicated that the aircraft should attract as little attention as possible. A Mirage sent in at 200 feet was to attract as little attention as possible! Perhaps it was believed that the operation could really be a mirage or that the pilot might attempt to fly backwards.

Secondly, we were told that when the F111 was finally sent in it did not attract any attention: ' . . . there is no widespread public knowledge of this RF-111 mission at present'. The Attorney-General was assured that at the moment nobody knew about the F111. It was also said that the Attorney was told that the flight would be at 30,000 feet, so that it would not disturb the Tasmanians. I would like to point out that Tasmanians do not scare easily. I invite the Attorney-General to recall what happened on 5 March. Then he will understand exactly what I have said-Tasmanians do not scare easily.

We were assured by the Defence Minister that he was advised it was a re-routed training flight, yet we have information in these papers that Mr Glare asked Squadron Leader Kennedy about the availability of flights and was told that the reconnaissance aircraft was not available; that No. 6 Squadron would need to have a special camera fitted at the special air navigation unit at East Sale. So it was not just a reconnaissance flight that was sent out; a lot had to be done. I believe that a tremendous amount of work had to be undertaken on the F111 to make it adaptable.

The most important thing I find in reading the papers is in regard to the timing of the request by the Attorney-General to the Minister for Defence. Tuesday, 5 April, appears to have been a very busy day. At 9.30 a.m. Mr Len Glare, the Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, through a personal friend, made the necessary inquiries regarding the availability of aerial photographs. Some time later that day he met the Attorney-General and was asked by him if permission was needed from the Minister for Defence. He answered that it was and the Attorney-General said that he would ring the Minister-ring him, not talk directly to him. Mr Glare was told a short time later that permission had been granted. This occurred on Tuesday, 5 April, at some point between 9.30 in the morning and one o'clock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one o'clock. Read the other minute.

—I have read all of the minutes. According to the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Staff, Mr Glare rang at one o'clock on 5 April and said that permission had been granted. There was no query about that statement.

—Have you read Mr Glare's subsequent minute in which the officer in question cheerfully changes his mind and says he was wrong? It was three o'clock. Come on, be honest. The papers are in front of you.

—Then we have the situation that at one o'clock Mr Glare rang Group Captain Waterfield and said, as I have stated, that the Minister had given permission, and procedures went ahead. Because the Minister had given permission Mr Glare was given direct liaison with Headquarters Operation Command and consequently no superior officers were told. Then we come to the three letters that I believe are the most important. Senator Gareth Evans, in his letter of 6 April, said to the Minister for Defence:

SPEECH.PARA: My Department will be getting in touch with the Director of Air Force Operations later today-
That was 6 April. Indeed, it had already been done on 5 April. We then have the letter of 12 April from Mr Scholes in which he says:
As I recall our conversation following the Cabinet Meeting on Tuesday 5th April , you asked if I would agree to utilise an F111 over Tasmania . . .
I understood that arangements had been made and it was to take place at 1500.

It was to take place at 1500 hours. The Minister for Defence said that the meeting took place following the Cabinet meeting. Senator Gareth Evans, in his letter of 20 April, says, no, he met the Minister before the Cabinet meeting; he spoke to him before 2.30 p.m. Thus, we have a situation in which Mr Len Glare, according to the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Staff, rang Group Captain Waterfield at one o'clock--

TALK.START.PARA: —Three o'clock.
—Mr Glare says that he thought it was about 3 p.m.
—So does Group Captain Waterfield; why don't you read it?

—But the direction we have before us states that it was definitely given at one o'clock. Group Captain Waterfield makes no comment regarding the time. I refer to the minute by the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Staff which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Glare telephoned Group Captain Waterfield at about 1300 hours on 5 April.
That is, one o'clock. He states further:

He requested urgent photographic coverage of the Franklin dam area, 'ideally before the Court hearing began'. He assured GPCAPT Waterfield that the Minister for Defence had approved the proposal and that a written request would follow.
On that basis, GPCAPT Waterfield authorised direct liaison between Mr Glare and HQ Operations Command on details of the request.

That was at one o'clock. Senator Gareth Evans said he verbally asked permission of the Minister for Defence at 2.30. The Minister for Defence said it was quite a considerable time later, and Senator Gareth Evans assured us that no arrangements were made anyway until the following day, 6 April. This place has been misled by the Attorney-General. Because he has been caught with his pants down, with his streaker's defence, he has tried to get out of this in the most flippant of manners. He has used his portfolio, which is one of the most responsible of this Government, with all the security associated with it, in the most flippant manner possible. He has assured us, and he has tabled a document today relating to defence force aid to the civil powers. He has gone on with that. When were those procedures brought in? They were introduced in September 1978 and they were laid down especially to overcome the difficulties and the anomalies that were apparent during the Cyclone Tracy disaster. They have nothing to do with areas like the South West of Tasmania or anything similar. They were brought in and laid down to overcome the problems associated with Cyclone Tracy. Senator Evans is now attempting to use them to enable the Commonwealth to spy on our State's affairs to obtain evidence for a court case.

Mr Deputy President, I believe there are a lot more questions to be answered in relation to the tabling of the documents. I have many more questions on those documents that I believe need an answer, and I am only too sorry that my time has now expired and I am unable to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I first congratulate you on your accession to this post. I am sure we will have co-operation from you and that you will have co-operation from us in the future. Nothing would demonstrate more why we are sitting on this side of the House and why members of the former Government are sitting on that side of the House than the performances today in Question Time, the bringing forward of this matter of public importance, and the performances of some members- unfortunately, some of the Tasmanian members-of the House of Representatives last night. We in this country are faced with record unemployment, a record Budget deficit, an economic recession of unprecedented proportions since the 1930s and a problem between the Tasmanian and Federal governments over the proposed construction of a dam. We have profound problems in the State of Tasmania where more than 20,000 people are unemployed and industry is running down. We have a great need for proper economic development in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues and I, none of whom has ever faced a Question Time before, entered this Parliament with the Opposition insisting that we have a Question Time on the opening day and that we sit two days rather than one. One presumes that was so that they could have another crack at us at Question Time. Now, after two Question Times and with the opportunity presented by the discussion of a matter of public importance, practically no questions have been asked about the state of the economy in this country or about the number of unemployed. We have just had a series of nit-picking questions about this incident. The only subject that the Opposition is willing to bring up as a matter of public importance is these military flights. I suggest that it is a pathetic performance. I suggest that it demonstrates--

TALK.START.PARA: —You ask the people back home what they think. You ought to go back to your State for a while.

—It demonstrates, Senator Walters, through you, Mr Deputy President, why you are sitting way back there and why we are sitting on this side. Senator Walters, in her usual manner, indulges in the sort of personal attack she carried out on the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). She spent 10 minutes talking about the time of one o'clock; about a minute that was tabled in this place by Senator Evans, among many other minutes. Of course, she refused repeatedly to turn a few pages to find the second minute which Mr Glare, the Deputy Secretary, gave to Senator Evans and in which he explained how it was his understanding that the phone call was in fact a couple of hours later. Group Captain Waterfield did not dispute the fact that that recollection was right. The whole basis of Senator Walters's argument seemed to be about this one o' clock-3 o'clock nonsense. That was the best she could do. She spent 10 minutes of her 15 minutes on that aspect and then bewailed the fact that she did not have more time to go on with similar nonsense, I suppose.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to repeat that Senator Evans made a decision to use military aircraft in this situation. It is a decision which he has admitted was unwise. It is a decision that the Government has admitted was unwise. He came into this place yesterday and today and tabled a great volume of documents. He has appeared on television and in front of the National Press Club and has been open . He has explained what happened, how he regretted what happened and why it happened. Yet we have the extraordinary circumstance of Senator Durack coming in here and presenting a matter of public importance which refers to 'the ineptitude of the Attorney-General' and the 'spy planes fiasco'. The subject matter contains emotive terms like this. Senator Durack suggested during the discussion of this matter of public importance that Senator Evans has failed to explain his actions in any credible sense.

The fact that this matter of public importance has been raised may surprise the people in this country. They may have thought the Opposition would have had more serious things to bring up as matters of public importance. Senator Durack, who brought forward this matter of public importance and used terms such as ' incredible events' and 'total ineptitude', has a record, as Attorney-General, for those very things beyond comparison in this country. I remind honourable senators of the times we spent in this place considering bottom-of-the-harbour tax dodging and the activities of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. I remind honourable senators of the difficulty we had in dragging information out of the very man who brought forward this matter of public importance today. We spent day after day and week after week until we finally got to the bottom of the situation-although I am not sure that we ever did get to the bottom of it.

Senator Evans, in comparison with that, came into this place, tabled all the documents and answered every question that has been put to him, both inside this place and outside this place. To suggest for a minute that he has not been able to explain his actions in any credible sense and that he has been reluctant to admit the error of his ways is, I think, an incredible statement to make. The thing that seems to worry Senator Walters and some of the members of the House of Representatives from Tasmania was that Senator Evans-he admitted that he was unwise to do so-asked that a military aircraft go down to Tasmania to take some photographs to assist in a court case which was coming up. Senator Walters and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) called in the past for the use of the military in Tasmania when there was an airlines dispute. In the last election campaign, Mr Anthony offered the services of the police to go and assist the State police in what was going on at the Franklin Dam at that time. I can remember Mr Hodgman, the honourable member for Denison, appearing on television and saying that he was proud that his Prime Minister was willing to use the Air Force in airlines disputes in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Goodluck called for the Army last week.

—Last week Mr Goodluck called for the Army to be sent into South West Tasmania to ensure that the Franklin Dam would be built. What sort of hypocrisy have we here? It ranks with the hypocrisy of the honourable member for Denison when he was in the upper House in Tasmania. He masquaeraded as an independent and called for national intervention and a national inquiry into the flooding of Lake Pedder because it was an area of national importance. This ranks with the hypocrisy of the former Minister for Administrative Services who I see at the moment is not even on the front bench of the Opposition. It ranks with his hypocrisy in announcing that the Federal Government was going to intervene in relation to Fraser Island against the wishes of the Queensland Government, against the wishes of the local trade union movement and against the then views of the Queensland Opposition on the basis that it was an area of national importance involving not only Queenslanders but also all Australians. We have this incredible performance by these people who see in the short term populace votes in this issue. They come along and do things such as Mr Newman did. He tried deliberately yesterday for publicity purposes to get himself thrown out of the House of Representatives. My colleague the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) very wisely did not fall for that one and did not call for Mr Newman to be thrown out. Mr Gray has been escalating this matter and trying to drum up violence on this issue for the last three or four months.
—That is an outrageous thing to say.

—He has used emotive terms continually about those who are demonstrating in the area. It is not an outrageous thing to say. He has said that if the Commonwealth policemen went into the area his local police would arrest the Commonwealth policemen. He had to be corrected by the secretary of the local police association who quite rightly said that the local police would not do this. He said that they would sit down and discuss with the Commonwealth Police what was to happen and pointed out that they would have to accept Commonwealth law under those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: This sad and sorry situation has been going on for weeks and weeks. Members of the Opposition, in the words of Senator Missen today, will grasp at any red herring to get away from what this debate really is about. It is about Tasmania' s economic development, the wisdom of putting all our eggs into this one basket as far as power development is concerned and the fact that we have more than 20, 000 people unemployed in Tasmania and a State Government that wishes to use this large amount of capital expenditure without any guarantee that any industrial development will result from it and without any overall economic plan for Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that it was provocative?

—The honourable senator asks whether I believe that the spy flight, as she calls it, was provocative. The expression is a ludicrous one. I do not believe that it was provocative. I believe that it was unwise. I believe that the so-called provocation has been nicely stirred up by Mr Gray, Senator Walters and their colleagues because they do not want to debate the real issues which are the real problems that face Tasmania. They are not concerned about the jobs of the workers on the West Coast. They are not concerned about the jobs of future Tasmanians. They are not concerned about the future development of Tasmania. They are concerned about their short term political futures. I think that is the problem which bedevils Tasmania at the moment. That is one of the problems that bedevil the whole economic situation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters told us that when we sit again she will ask many more questions . Apparently we will have to sit through two more Question Times during which time those people who bother to listen to parliamentary broadcasts in this country will be bored stiff by the sort of nit-picking nonsense that we have had during Question Time and the discussion of the matter of public importance today . I believe that they will reasonably ask themselves: 'What is the Opposition all about? Are its members really only concerned about the actions of the Attorney-General?' I remind the Senate: These are actions that the Attorney- General admits were unwise. He has said that they will not occur again. Will those listeners really be concerned about whether a telephone call was made at one o'clock one afternoon or at 3 o'clock one afternoon? Will they really be so concerned about a typographical error in a Press statement on which a member of the Opposition wastes a question by getting up and asking: 'Was it Thursday or Friday', or: 'Was it the 8th or the 9th?'. This is a pathetic performance. If Ministers of the previous Government had been as open and as willing to answer questions about difficult situations, as Senator Gareth Evans has been, if they had been willing to get up at the first opportunity, as Senator Gareth Evans has done, and table all relevant documents in this place and if they had been willing to be as open and as frank as he has been, some of them might have stayed Ministers a little bit longer and maybe-although even that would not have saved them-the previous Government might have stayed in government a little bit longer. The Opposition failed in government and, on the first two days of this Parliament, it has failed in opposition. I suspect that it will stay in opposition a long time. The Opposition should let us get on with the proper business that this Parliament is all about-and that is debating the real problems which face this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The total ineptitude of the Attorney-General in the Tasmanian spy planes fiasco , his failure to explain his actions in any credible sense and his utmost reluctance to admit the error of his ways.

The debate on this matter of public importance is quite justifiable in view of the fact that the spy flights deal with issues of Federal-State relations, democratic government in Australia, the integrity of the Australian defence forces and ministerial responsibility. On the previous occasion when the question of Defence Force aid to the civil power was debated in this Parliament, it was over the Hilton bombing affair. Even on that occasion some members of the then Opposition, including myself, questioned the appropriateness or otherwise of the use of defence forces in aid of the civil power at that time. Quite clearly, on this occasion there has been an unjustified and an unauthorised use of the Defence Force in aid of the civil power. That is a question that strikes at the heart of democracy. Let me prove to the Senate that the spy flights over Tasmania were unauthorised. It is already admitted that they were unjustified. This morning the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) tabled a document entitled 'Defence Instructions (General)' which dealt with the procedures to be followed when requests were made for Defence Force aid to the civil power. This is in situations other than counter-terrorist operations. The document is entitled 'Policy and procedures'. It is quite clear in that document that any request must be forwarded through and approved by the Chief of Defence Force Staff. In this case the CDFS was not even notified, let alone did he give approval. I quote from document 25 tabled by the Attorney-General, which is a note from the CDFS in which he says:
We discussed this matter very briefly on Monday the 11th of April-
That is, of course, after the flights-

and I now wish to advise you more formally of my concern regarding a number of aspects of the generation and handling of this task; in particular I am extremely concerned that the matter appears to have been handled as a routine task within your Directorate of Operations and authorization given without your or my knowledge. At the very least this action demonstrates a lack of awareness of the political sensitivities and even deeper consequences of the use of Defence Force assets in an issue such as the Franklin River Dam.

That note is from Sir Neville McNamara, the Air Chief Marshal, Chief of Australia's Defence Force. If that minute, which was tabled in the Parliament, revealing his concern about the misuse of the Defence Force in aid of the civil power, is not a matter of public importance, I do not know what is. Nor were the flights authorised by the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes).

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.
—No document is contained in the documents which the Attorney- General tabled which gives authorisation.
—Are you accusing me of lying?
—That remains to be seen, perhaps the week after next.
—You will have to establish your grounds very firmly before you do that.

—I put myself in the same position that the Attorney-General was in when he attacked the previous Attorney-General. He was questioning him, almost calling him a liar, on the matter of no documents being tabled. Now there is no document. Frank Cranston, in the Canberra Times today, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The documents indicate also that Mr Scholes never formally authorised the flights but they were approved by a RAAF officer at the request of a deputy secretary in the Attorney-General's Department, who was a personal friend.

There are no documents here which show that despite the fact that the Minister for Defence requested the Attorney-General to put the request in writing he has not responded in turn. That is an argument for the Attorney-General to take up with him but the proper procedure to be followed would have been for it to be authorised in accordance with the document which the Attorney-General tabled today from the Minister for Defence. Paragraph 14 of that document states:

Members of the Defence Force providing aid to the civil power are to remain under Defence Force command, and the commander of the Defence Force element is to act in accordance with directions given by the Minister for Defence and subsequently issued through command channels.

That was not even done on this occasion. The Attorney-General must admit that. According to the documents that he has placed before the Parliament it is quite clear that it was he and his Department which made the request and the individual directions were made through his Department to the lower ranks in the Royal Australian Air Force and not through the proper command channels. Surely that is a matter of grave concern to this Parliament which is interested in the upholding of civil liberties, which is interested in the upholding of the Constitution and which is interested particularly in the upholding of the integrity of the Defence Force of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to read out the rest of that document, including paragraphs 17 and 18?

—The document has been tabled and I will not waste the time I have reading out the rest of it. Despite what Senator Grimes has just said-he refused to admit that it was provocative-the Attorney-General, did say in his defence, that it was extraordinarily provocative. That was Senator Evans's response today. He now admits that the spy flights were extraordinarily provocative.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other questions of importance will emerge. For example, we have not been told what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said. I will come to that in a few moments. There is no documentation at all of that, no letter from the Prime Minister, in the documents that have been tabled. There is not even a note as to what he said. Maybe it would need to have been written on asbestos paper. There is another aspect of this matter which would interest the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley). In the normal course of events all air traffic controllers in south-eastern Australia would have been advised of the flights, if only for the reason that they might have been vectoring a civil aircraft in the same flight path. Telex No. 536, document 3 of the tabled Defence Department documents, at item U states:
Aircraft should attract as little attention as possible.

Two questions arise from that. Firstly, was this instruction spontaneously evolved in the Air Force or was it on the advice of the client department; namely, the Attorney-General's Department? Secondly, I point out that amongst all of the detailed documents we have there is no telex or record of any advice having been given to air traffic controllers in south-eastern Australia, to Launceston control or to the Hydro-Electric Commission operations unit in South- West Tasmania which has helicopters operating in that area. There is nothing in the document to say that that advice was given. One assumes and hopes that it was. Just for the record, I would like to know between now and two weeks' time when were the appropriate traffic controllers advised and who were they. The Attorney-General, having admitted that it was an extraordinarily provocative action and that it showed his political unwisdom-they are his words-has said that he has been prepared to eat and has eaten humble pie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lots.

—Lots; bags of humble pie. That is good enough for schoolboys but it is not good enough for a Minister. A Minister should stand up on a matter of such public importance. The integrity of the Defence Force is at stake and the misuse of the Defence Force in the aiding of the civil power is unwarranted and unjustified. Senator Grimes did not address the issue at all. All he said was that there were not a great many questions on unemployment. There were a number of questions on this issue. The Notice Paper shows that the National Economic Summit Conference documents are going to be tabled in the Parliament. I have not seen them tabled as yet.
—They were tabled last night.
—I am sorry. I have not got them.
—That shows your sense of priorities.

—My sense of priorities was to tackle those documents because one issue relating to unemployment was not even mentioned at the Summit. I find that quite extraordinary. I will leave that matter to another time. Let me come back to the fact that there are no documents before us containing the responses of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this matter. The Prime Minister of Australia was elected on the slogan 'Bringing Australians Together'. The type of action that has been taken by the Attorney-General is going to split Australia and it is going to go to the heart of the Federation. If I were the Attorney-General I would accept the criticism like a man and, over this issue, I would very seriously consider resigning. Unless he does resign, any future proposals brought in by him will have us wondering whether they contain the characteristics of fairness, reasonableness, reserve and respect for the opinions of others-qualities which should be possessed by an Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia. These qualities have not been shown in this spy flight issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are at the beginning of a new session of parliament, the Thirty-third Parliament. Yesterday we were all sworn in. There was great ceremony. The Governor-General spoke to us and bands played. It was a portentous occasion. The conservative coalition now in opposition is flexing its muscles. We are now engaged in the first significant exercise of criticism available to the Opposition in the Senate-that is, of course, a matter of public importance. That is a vehicle of the greatest significance in the democracy of this country and in the values and operation of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I cast my mind over the many urgent problems that confront this nation at the present time. They include the state of the economy, unemployment and how we are going to cope with automation. Those problems are there in serried ranks. They all demand urgent attention. Indeed, there are many themes of great public importance, of real public importance, that I suggest to the new Opposition it might have chosen with some justification and dignity. Instead we find this lightweight Gilbert and Sullivan-type issue. It is such a Mickey Mouse-type issue in fact that as a party the Australian Democrats found some difficulty in steeling ourselves to take part in it. But there are some things that need to be said and we intend to say them. I must say to members of the coalition parties, more in sadness than in anger, that we hope that they settle down soon and start aiming their guns in more suitable and useful directions. When that happens we will be glad to join them in carrying out the proper function that we and the Opposition have of criticising the Government, of testing it and attacking it, where necessary, for what it is doing on matters of consequence and substance.

For a variety of reasons the Australian Democrats do not support this matter of public importance in the context I have described. This is the beginning of a new parliament and a matter such as this should not have been brought to this Senate today. As a consequence, we attack and oppose the proposition. To support that view, I begin by quoting from a distinguished compatriot of all honourable senators, Spike Milligan. He is one of many members of the public who have been thoroughly bewildered by this extraordinary manifestation on the political scene at this time-the so-called spy flight issue. The words 'spy flight' are very serious and portentous words to use. They have connotations of enmity, violence and foreign states which have to be attacked. I suggest to honourable senators that there is a degree of mischief in the use of those words which this nation ought not to tolerate. I refer again to Spike Milligan because I think his comments are a very good beginning to what I want to say. A letter appeared in the Weekend Australian of 16 and 17 April. It stated:
As Alice said . . .
Unless I am losing my reason, do I understand (Franklin River dam) the RAAF is not allowed to fly over Australian territory. As Alice said. 'It's all very strange.'-Spike Milligan, Woy Woy, N.S.W.

I find myself very much in agreement with the opinion expressed by Spike Milligan. A number of other people who have written to the newspapers have taken that view. One might ask, with good reason, just what all this fuss is about. Is Tasmania after all an enemy or a foreign state? Is it a place that is on the point of seceding? Is it a sort of Falklands Island that is not part of this country? Have we really reached the stage where we cannot say any more that there is only one sovereign state on this continent and the islands off it and that that nation and sovereign state is called Australia? I find it incredible that we have reached the stage where it has become an issue of criticism that Australian military aircraft fly over Australian soil. That is not to say that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), although he seems to have admitted to the first part of what is contained in this matter of public importance, was totally inept. He has not admitted that but he has admitted to a degree of ineptitude. If he had done that, far be it from me to have to defend him.

I will deal with other points raised in the matter of public importance as I come to them. I think that the intent of this matter of public importance is to create mischief. Indeed, other areas of debate concerning South West Tasmania do have this element of mischief. They do raise, inappropriately and excessively, the totally specious issue of States' rights. That is not to say that States' rights are not important or valuable because of course they are. The Australian Democrats are the first people to support States' rights. Devolution of power is a part of our policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what that means.

—Senator Walters can read our policy any time. I will send her copies of it so that she can inform herself of our policies and improve her mind . In Australia we have a three-tiered system of government. For instance, local authorities, councils and the like are regularly overruled by State governments in what is seen as an overriding State interest that should prevail over purely local considerations. That happens virtually every day. Members of the coalition parties do not jump up and down about it. It is a reasonable part of the devolution of power. It seems to me equally reasonable that the same process should prevail when something which is demonstrably of national or international importance is going on in any part of Australia. It ought to be a matter in which the Federal Government is able to take some action.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a plain need and a reasonable case for the Commonwealth to act in this regard. I must go as far as to say that those persons who are taking a strong view on this issue are divisive in the community. In my opinion they are meddling with something which is very dangerous indeed. It is dangerous, for example, that Queenslanders should be set against New South Welshmen and that Tasmanians should be set against Victorians. It is dangerous that indeed we should preside over some sort of idiotic Balkanisation of this great Commonwealth and destroy it by creating this sort of idiotic minuscule issue. It is that. I will examine that as I proceed. Let us look at the text of the matter of public importance. It states:
The total ineptitude of the Attorney-General in the Tasmanian spy planes fiasco -
As I have said, the Attorney-General has admitted to that degree of ineptitude. I would not have done so in his place but that is his business. The matter of public importance continues:
his failure to explain his actions in any credible sense-

That is the second point which has been raised. I find that very difficult to swallow as well. The reference to the Attorney-General's alleged failure to explain his actions seems to be quite extraordinary. As I said, I am not here to defend Senator Gareth Evans. I feel he is big enough and probably ugly enough to take care of himself. However, I would say that far from failing to explain his actions he seems to us to have overreacted and to have allowed his own statements and actions in this matter to bring it to a degree of importance which it certainly does not deserve. The Attorney tabled a bundle of 77 pages of documents yesterday. An inordinate amount of Question Time during this sitting has been taken up with repetitious and, I suggest, to the public, boring explanations of this not very interesting matter. To that extent, the Opposition is directly to blame. It has laboured mightily and brought forward a mouse. It is time that that tiny corpse was decently buried.

I turn to the third part of the matter of public importance, the Attorney- General's alleged reluctance to admit the error of his ways. This is a very broad statement, that the Attorney-General is in error in his ways and that he has committed error in some respect. It relates, of course, directly to the justification for the Attorney doing what he did; that is, taking photographs to satisfy himself and the Government of the actual extent of damage to South West Tasmania by the preliminary works for the Gordon below Franklin Dam now being carried out by the Tasmanian Government. He did this through the use of a Royal Australian Air Force photographic survey operation. He has said-and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as we understand it, has said-that this was wrong and ought not to have been done. I concede to an extent that due to the circumstances of the extreme division of opinion, especially in Tasmania, about the Gordon below Franklin Dam, it was unfortunate that that should have been done. But I believe in the principle I stated earlier. The more important principle is that one of our defence aircraft ought to be able to fly freely over any part of Australia without any kind of criticism. I suggest that we cannot allow ourselves to obscure that principle, in the interests of whatever might happen in future. At some future time-who knows-any idiotic government might, by some aberration of the electoral processes, come to power in one State in this country. We do not know whether that might happen. How far would that government be allowed to go? Would there be any feeling that it should be immune from any kind of interest, activity or investigation from any other part of Australia? Was that the purpose of the founding of this great Commonwealth? I suggest not.

I return directly to the Minister's justification because that is the last and, I think, the most important part of Senator Durack's proposal. He referred to the error of the Attorney-General's ways. It is a fact that most Australians- some 55 per cent-do not want the Gordon below Franklin Dam. I believe that relates directly to the fact that the Liberal-National Party Coalition now sits on the Opposition benches and the Australian Labor Party sits on the Government benches. The Government-I applaud it for this-is properly and promptly carrying out the undertaking it made to the electorate, the majority of which, I repeat, does not want South West Tasmania vandalised. The Government is attempting to get ahead as fast as it can to correct the situation and do what it said it would do during the election campaign. This issue, as we know from the wide interest that it has awoken in the community, was one of the more important elements in the election of the Government.

It is very sad and directly relevant to this debate that massive destruction is now going on within the World Heritage area. This is not merely speculation on my part; it is the case as told by an authority on South West Tasmania who has just returned from the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —A RAAF pilot?

—I refer to Mr Peter Waterman, a renowned environmental scientist. Indeed, Senator Baume, he was appointed by the previous Government-your Government-to head the South West Tasmania Resources Survey, the only total inventory ever made of the wealth of natural, scientific and biological resources of that magnificent area. I am sure that the honourable senator will agree that Mr Waterman is an observer of some consequence. Mr Waterman has observed first-hand the moving in by the Hydro-Electric Commission of heavy earthmoving and grading equipment. This is speeding up the physical damage in the area, particularly the access roads. This is part of the Attorney-General's motivation. I cannot see that he has erred in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: While the physical destruction is serious enough, I must raise one other matter which is even more dangerous and worrying. The equipment that is being moved in has not been sterilised or washed in any way. One of the most insidious forms of destruction, often ignored when the sight of trees being hacked down is focused on, is the biological destruction caused by the intrusion of new diseases. Honourable senators should take note of this point. This biological destruction, which is savage, long-term and completely pervasive, has actually begun in South West Tasmania. Mr Waterman, on the best authority, says that a tree root-rot disease known as phytophthora cinnamomi has already been isolated within the World Heritage area. I repeat that its effects are already evident in plant life around the dam site and can be expected to spread. South West Tasmania could then become another New England plateau, a place of dead trees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was carried in by the demonstrators.
—If Senator Walters wants her State destroyed to that extent, she is going the right way about it. I am deeply disappointed--
—I think it should be on the record that Senator Walters said the disease was carried in by the demonstrators.

—I suggest that Senator Walters might like to give more thought to her statement that it was carried in by the demonstrators. The evidence that has been given by Mr Waterman is that it was definitely carried in by the heavy machinery. There is evidence to that effect. Yesterday I wrote to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) urging the Government to pass the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill as soon as possible-in fact, by today if possible-because of the urgency of this new problem. I am deeply disappointed that the House of Representatives has adjourned without doing so. These facts are vital because this situation-as well as, I stress the provocative and confrontationist nature of the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Gray-is the context in which overflights and photographic evidence were needed. I believe that although it was, perhaps, unfortunate that the Minister used military aircraft he was perfectly justified in seeking to obtain evidence through their use.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, another issue which has emerged in this matter only today is whether the photographs taken by the RAAF aircraft should be used in evidence. One presumes that if they are not used some other kind of aircraft will be used to take photographs. One set of photographs will not differ significantly from others. The net result-the only difference-will be that another aircraft will have to be sent because of all of this nonsense. The Australian taxpayer will have to foot the bill and will be worse off to that extent. If the Opposition believes that that is a desirable consummation it should think again.

The Government ought to call to mind that it is a government, and not a pack of children to be panicked as it has been over this tiny issue. It has many tasks of great importance and of great urgency to carry out in this country. The Attorney-General ought to address himself to the details of the revision of the Freedom of Information Act and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act, which he has already said he will do, rather than allow himself to be diverted week after week, day after day, by this pathetic political drum up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The total ineptitude of the Attorney-General in the Tasmanian spy planes fiasco , his failure to explain his actions in any credible sense and his utmost reluctance to admit the error of his ways.

This is not a debate about South West Tasmania; it is a debate which distinguishes between ends and means. Senator Mason either has not understood again or has chosen to present an argument about ends when the debate is about the process that has gone on and about how wrong this process has been. Senator Mason reminds me of that speaker described by Winston Churchill, when he said:

He can best be described as one of those orators who, before they get up, do not know what they are going to say; when they are speaking, do not know what they are saying; and, when they have sat down, do not know what they have said.

The honourable senator apparently does not even comprehend now how foolish his argument has been. This is an argument about Australia, the constitutional relationship between the Commonwealth and the States, and proper dealings between governments. Senator Gareth Evans-or 'I the Attorney-General' as he referred to himself-acknowledged that he had been foolish. He acknowledged political unwisdom. He acknowledged a lack of 'eptitude'-that was his word-but he said: 'I do not need more criticism in this place'. How dare he say that! He may now be a member of the Executive Government; he may be a summiteer; but Senator Evans is still a member of the Parliament and he is answerable in the Parliament for what he does as a Minister. This is the place in which he is brought to account. It is proper that he should be brought to account here, in spite of Senator Mason and the other Australian Democrats believing that it is not right to raise this matter for discussion. He is a member of the Parliament and is answerable here to the people.

The expectations of Australians are that they will have good, efficient, effective government. But they expect a government that will show sensitivity to the Constitution, that will show sensitivity to the constitutional niceties and relationships which exist and that will show respect for the rights of Australian citizens as they are guaranteed under the Constitution and under arrangements. The Australian newspaper formed its view of the events that have taken place. On 21 April in its editorial it stated:
. . . the decision he-
That is, Senator Gareth Evans-
and the Defence Minister, Mr Scholes, made to use RAAF aircraft to gather evidence against a sovereign state represent a dangerous constitutional precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that article referring to-a sovereign State?

—Senator Mason, having made a mess of his speech, cannot stop chattering away. The Australian newspaper stated further that Senator Evans , in attempting to excuse his actions, showed 'a remarkable incapacity to comprehend the potential constitutional damage and the very real political damage the affair has created'. That is what this is about. Another newspaper, the Age, made the comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Using the air force earlier in the week was at the very least crass; at the worst, provocative and irresponsible. Mr Gray has every right to object.

That is what this debate is about. It is not about whether a dam should be built . That issue will be determined properly through established process. It is about the failure to follow proper process that has been a feature of Senator Evans's very unfortunate actions in this place. The threat of the misuse of the defence forces is or should be of concern to everyone in the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly to civil libertarians.

—Especially to civil libertarians; I am indebted to Senator Harradine. The misuse of the defence forces is the stuff of the coup d'etat; it is the stuff of revolution. We as parliamentarians have a responsibility to question and to bring to account anyone who at any time in any place uses improperly the defence forces of this country in a way in which they were not meant to be used. Tasmania, we know, objected to this misuse of the defence forces. Mr Gray said it was another covert use of the defence forces. The territories are concerned. I thought Mr Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, expressed the whole problem very well. On the PM program of 11 April Mr Everingham put it in very reasonable terms when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a conflict, a dispute between Tasmania and the Commonwealth over what is a proposition that has been supported by the Tasmanian people, namely, to build a dam. On the other hand, the Federal Government has a mandate to stop that dam. It is one of the most highly emotional conflicts that has ever happened in Australian politics and to bring the defence forces into it is an act of almost incredible obtuseness.

That is what we are objecting to. We are objecting to the action of the Attorney -General using the defence forces. The question to be resolved can be resolved. The question of the Franklin Dam can be resolved by established civil process. I say to Senator Mason: If it is necessary to obtain aerial photographic evidence, obtain it, but do it in an appropriate way; do not misuse the defence forces of this country. I am surprised that the Australian Democrats cannot grasp that fact. There is no objection to the gathering of evidence for any proper Commonwealth purpose provided that it is done by proper Commonwealth means and using proper Commonwealth power. The argument here is with the improper, inappropriate use of Commonwealth power by someone who is already, obviously, an accident-prone Attorney-General.

The use of the defence forces in this case was wrong. It was wrong and it has been recognised as being wrong. The Attorney-General, Senator Evans, requested a flight that should never have been sought. He pressed that request when he should never have pressed it. He was slow in providing the written request. In fact, the written request from the Attorney-General did not arrive before the flight was made, so the documentation was inadequate. The flights represented a breach of proper procedure. They were a breach of proper practice. They were a breach of the proper means of dealing between the pieces that make up our Commonwealth, between the governments of the Commonwealth and the States.

It is important in a federation that there be trust and fair dealing between governments; that there be rules which are understood and which are followed. The action of the Labor Government in authorising these spy flights has been a breach of trust. It has been a breach of fair dealing. It has been a breach of the existing rules and it deserves to be condemned on each of those grounds. The proposition I put to the Government is that the end being sought does not justify the means used to achieve it. The means used here were improper and inappropriate and in fact have been condemned widely.

Let me ask members of the Senate on the Labor side, through you, Mr Deputy President, how they would feel about the inappropriate use of the defence forces in, say, a circumstance in which there was a need to break a strike. They would object to the inappropriate use of the defence forces, as everyone would object, and I cannot understand why they find it difficult on this occasion to recognise that the Attorney-General who sits in front of them has done no service to the country, no service to the Government and certainly no service to himself. In his apologia, Senator Gareth Evans seems not to have learned what the issues are . The Adelaide Advertiser tried to put the questions for him when it stated:
It is a little disturbing that Senator Evans, despite his reprimand, seems still to have difficulty in understanding why the Mirage flight should not have been made.
It also stated:
Above all, the political sensitivity inevitably associated with the use of the RAAF for that purpose should have been readily apparent to a Federal Minister.

The whole affair has been a fiasco. It has been rejected by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). Senator Evans has been rejected by his former colleague Mr Wriedt, in his comments about the whole matter. Senator Evans and his Government are now the butt of satire all around Australia. I refer honourable senators to the very good cartoon which appeared in today's Australian in which the streaker's defence was given its proper treatment. The answers given to questions today and yesterday have been inadequate. It has been a pathetic affair. Senator Evans aspires to be the first law officer of the Commonwealth and to earn respect in that position. So far what he has evoked in people is a sense of deja vu. Our minds go back to 1973. We have a clear memory of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation raid by Senator Murphy, the then Attorney-General. I remind honourable senators that that affair-and the problem Senator Murphy had following that-was one from which he never recovered.

This episode has been a very unsavoury one. It has done no good to this Government. Senator Evans has let his Government down at its first test. We have seen the most powerful Government in Australia use its might incorrectly and improperly against the smallest State. It has used it covertly and it has sought to justify what it has done because it believes the end is appropriate. Australians are concerned with process. They are concerned with due process. They are concerned that the military should be under proper control of the civil authorities and that that control should follow the rules. That has not been the case throughout this spy plane affair. The questions which have been asked by Senator Durack and by my colleagues in the last two days have done a service to the people of Australia. They have brought to light documents and they have brought to light facts. I do not believe that the affair ends there. It has done Senator Evans no credit and I believe the matter of public importance is one which properly needed to be raised.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) agreed to:
That, in pursuance of section 13 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth, the Senators chosen for each State shall be divided into two classes, as follows:
(1) The name of the Senator first elected shall be placed first on the Senators ' Roll for each State and the name of the Senator next elected shall be placed next, and so on in rotation.

(2) The Senators whose names are placed first, second, third, fourth and fifth on the Roll shall be Senators of the second class, that is, the long-term Senators, and Senators whose names are placed sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth and tenth on the Roll shall be Senators of the first class, that is, the short-term Senators.
Motion (by Senator Grimes for Senator Button) proposed:

(1) Days and Hours of Meeting: That, unless otherwise ordered, the days and hours of meeting of the Senate shall be Tuesday at fifteen minutes to two p.m., Wednesdays at half-past eleven a.m., and Thursday at ten a.m.

(2) Suspension of Sittings: That, unless otherwise ordered, on Wednesdays, the sittings of the Senate, or of a Committee of the Whole, shall be suspended from one p.m. till fifteen minutes past two p.m. and from half-past six p.m. till eight p.m.

(3) Adjournment of the Senate: That, unless otherwise ordered, at seven p.m. on Tuesdays, half-past ten p.m. on Wednesdays and seven p.m. on Thursdays the President shall put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn-which Question shall be open to debate; if the Senate be in Committee at that hour, the Chairman shall in like manner put the Question-That he do leave the Chair and report to the Senate; and upon such report being made the President shall forthwith put the Question-That the Senate do now adjourn-which Question shall be open to debate: Provided that if the Senate or the Committee be in Division at the time named, the President or the Chairman shall not put the Question referred to till the result of such Division has been declared; and if the business under discussion shall not have been disposed of at such adjournment it shall appear on the Notice Paper for the next sitting day.

(4) Routine of Business: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders and unless otherwise ordered, on Thursdays, the Senate shall proceed with its ordinary business in the following routine:
1. Petitions
2. Notices
3. Formal Motions
4. Postponement of Business
5. Motions and Orders of the Day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper
6. At 12 o'clock midday, Questions
7. Further Motions and Orders of the Day, or vice versa, as set down on the Notice Paper.

(5) Government and General Business-Precedence: That, on all sitting days of the Senate, unless otherwise ordered, Government Business shall take precedence of General Business, except that General Business shall take precedence of Government Business on Thursdays, from a quarter-past two p.m. until the expiration of two and one half-hours or until there is no further debate; and that, unless otherwise ordered, General Business Orders of the Day shall take precedence of General Business Notices of Motion on alternate Thursdays.
(6) Petitions-Procedure for Presentation: That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the procedure for the presentation of Petitions be as follows:
(1) A Senator wishing to present a petition shall lodge it with the Clerk.

(2) The Clerk shall make an announcement in respect of petitions lodged with him, indicating in respect of each petition the Senator who presents it, the number of signatures, and the subject matter of the petition.
(3) Every petition so presented shall be deemed to have been received by the Senate unless a motion, moved forthwith, that a particular petition be not received, be agreed to.
(4) The terms of the petitions presented shall be printed in Hansard.
(7) Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees-Reference of Annual Reports:

(1) That, unless otherwise ordered, all annual reports of Government departments and authorities, including statutory corporations, laid on the Table of the Senate, shall stand referred, without any Question being put, for consideration and, if necessary, for report thereon, to the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees.
(2) That the President shall transmit a copy of each report so tabled to the Committee which he deems appropriate.

(3) That the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees may, at their discretion, pursue or not pursue inquiries into reports so received; but any action necessary, arising from a report of a Committee, shall be taken in the Senate on motion after notice.

(8) Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees-Reference of Bills: That, after the Second Reading of a Bill (other than an Appropriation Bill, Supply Bill, or Bill imposing taxation), and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders and without limiting the operation of Standing Orders 36AA and 196A, the following procedure shall apply-

(1) A motion (of which notice need not be given) may be moved to refer the Bill to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee: Provided that if no such motion be moved, or if moved and negatived, the Senate shall forthwith resolve itself into a Committee of the Whole for consideration of the Bill.

(2) Upon motion to refer a Bill to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee, no debate thereon shall be allowed for more than one hour, and in speaking thereon no Senator shall exceed ten minutes. If the debate be not sooner concluded then forthwith upon the expiration of that time the President shall put any Questions on any amendment or motion already proposed from the Chair.

(3) On reference of a Bill to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee, a day shall be fixed for the reporting of a Committee's proceedings to the Senate, by which day the final report of the Committee shall be brought up, unless further time be moved for and granted: Provided that the Senate may at any time prior to such day receive the final report of the Committee.

(4) Upon a Bill being committed to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee pursuant to this Order, it shall be set down on the Notice Paper as an Order of the Day for further consideration following report from the Committee.

(5) The procedure to be adopted by a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee shall, as far as possible, be the same as that in Committee of the Whole: Provided that a Committee may ask for explanations from the Minister in Charge of a Bill, or officers, relating to the clauses of the Bill.

(6) A Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee shall have no power to make amendments to a Bill, but may recommend amendments or requests for amendments. No amendment or request for amendment may be proposed which would not be in order if proposed in a Committee of the Whole.

(7) A report from a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee, relating to a Bill, shall be received by the Senate without debate and its consideration deferred until the reading of the Order of the Day for the further consideration of the Bill, when the procedure, unless otherwise ordered, shall be as follows:
(a) a motion may be proposed that the report be adopted; and such motion shall be open to debate;
(b) on the motion for the adoption of the report, amendments may be proposed;
(c) in these proceedings, the same right of speech and time limits shall apply as in debate in Committee of the Whole;

(d) if amendments or requests for amendments be made, additional to any recommended by the report of a Standing Committee, the Chair shall propose a Question-That the Bill as reported (with or without amendments or requests for amendments), and as further amended, be agreed to;

(e) a motion may be moved, by any Senator, that the Bill as reported from a Standing Committee be recommitted, in whole or in part, to the Standing Committee, or that the Bill as reported be committed, in whole or in part, to a Committee of the Whole; and
(f) when the report from the Committee, or from a Committee of the Whole, is finally adopted, the Bill may be proceeded with in the usual way.

(9) Consideration of Government Papers: (1) That, unless otherwise ordered and notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, on Tuesdays after Questions without Notice, and Wednesdays and Thursdays after Notices of Motion, Papers may be presented by Ministers. Upon the presentation of such Papers, a Senator may move, without notice, that the Senate take note of one, or several, of the Papers. Senators may not speak to any such motion for more than five minutes. Any debate pursuant to this Sessional Order shall be interrupted after the expiration of 30 minutes or until there is no further debate:

Provided that, on Wednesdays, any debate pursuant to this Sessional Order shall be interrupted at 12 o'clock midday. Provided further that, at the conclusion of his or her speech, or, if the debate is interrupted pursuant to this Sessional Order, a Senator may move that the debate be resumed pursuant to Sessional Order on Thursdays at the time for consideration of General Business. At that time, further such motions may be moved with respect to any Government Paper tabled during the current sitting week and in relation to which no motion to take note has been moved. Debates on any such motion or motions shall take precedence of other General Business, but shall not continue beyond one hour.

(2) Where debates on motions moved under the provisions of this Sessional Order are adjourned and are called on in the normal course of business, Senators who have spoken to the Questions under the provisions of this Sessional Order may speak again for the time allowed under Standing Order 407A.

(10) Consideration of Committee Reports: (1) That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, and unless otherwise ordered, where in any week there are Orders of the Day for the resumption of debate on motions for the consideration or adoption of reports of committees-

(a) on Wednesdays after Questions without Notice, Orders of the Day relating to reports of committees presented to the Senate during that week shall be severally called on, in the order in which the respective reports were presented ;

(b) if there were no committee reports presented during that week, or if debate on motions relating to such reports concludes before the expiration of one hour, Orders of the Day relating to committee reports presented prior to that week shall then be severally called on in an order which is the reverse of the order in which the respective reports were presented;
(c) in any debate on such motions so called on, each Senator may speak for not more than 10 minutes; and
(d) any debate pursuant to this Sessional Order shall be interrupted after the expiration of one hour.

(2) Provided that, where debate on any motion debated under the provisions of this Sessional Order is adjourned or is interrupted under the provisions of this Sessional Order, Senators who have spoken to such motion under the provisions of this Sessional Order may speak again to the motion for the time allowed under Standing Order 407A, when the debate on the motion is again called on in the normal course of business.
(11) Time Limits to Speeches-Proposed Amendment to Standing Order 407A: That the following proposed amendment to Standing Order 407A operate as a Sessional Order for a trial period:

No Senator shall speak for more than thirty minutes in any debate in the Senate . Any Senator may move that the time limit of thirty minutes be extended for fifteen minutes; such motion shall forthwith be put without debate:
Provided that, where a right of reply is allowed in any debate, a Senator speaking in reply shall speak for not more than thirty minutes.
Provided further that, in debate on the first reading of a Bill which the Senate may not amend, no Senator shall speak for more than fifteen minutes.
In Committee no Senator shall speak for more than fifteen minutes at any one time on any one Question:

Provided that, where the speech of a Senator is interrupted by this provision, and no other Senator rises to speak, the Senator so interrupted may continue his speech for a further fifteen minutes but no longer continuously on any one Question.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I indicate to you, Mr President, and to the Senate that the Opposition is of the view that these sitting hours are not particularly satisfactory and in particular is concerned about the fact that both the House of Representatives and the Senate will be meeting on Wednesday mornings, thus removing the second free morning which has traditionally been part of the parliamentary week and which has permitted the meeting of the parties and the Cabinet or the shadow Cabinet, as the case may be. I acknowledge that, after discussions with the Government and with the Australian Democrats, there has been some concession with respect to the Senate alone; that is, to push the sitting hours on Wednesday back to 11.30 a.m. An hour of the hour and a half so lost has been made up by making minor adjustments elsewhere. The position was that overall the Government wished to pursue these hours. The Democrats, subject to the change that they were prepared to support, indicated they would support it for this session alone as a trial. On that basis and that basis only I propose to have this dealt with in a formal way. To avoid future misunderstandings with the Government I thought it desirable to put something as to our position on the Hansard record.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to make a request of the Government. When we were in government and the now Government was in opposition I understand that in rearranging our sitting hours we paid heed to the request from at least some members of the then Opposition that the Tuesday and Wednesday mornings should remain available for the reason I indicated earlier, so that Caucus and the shadow Cabinet could meet. The change in the Senate hours will be of assistance to us, but since the House of Representatives will still be sitting at 10 a.m. it is not as helpful as it would be if both Houses were brought into line. So I request the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to take up with the Government the possibility of making a similar adjustment to the sitting hours in the House of Representatives so that the parties will have the value of that additional time for the additional meetings of both parliamentary and party committees. The speech read as follows-

This Bill seeks supplementation of the provision made in the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 for financing 1982-83 expenditures to the extent that such expenditures as are appropriated from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) are likely to exceed the moneys legally available to that fund.

The Senate will be aware that expenditures from the CRF in any financial year may not exceed the moneys available to it. While there is standing authority to meet certain expenditures from Loan Fund, such as payments to or for the States for capital assistance and roads grants, successive governments have found it necessary to introduce legislation to authorise borrowings for and expenditure in respect of services for which the Parliament has appropriated moneys from the CRF. The simplest and traditional means of seeking such authority has been a Loan Bill for the purpose of funding defence expenditure from Loan Fund.

Such legislation does not therefore authorise expenditures in excess of those for which valid appropriations of the CRF already exist-other than expenditures in respect of the costs of the relevant borrowings; it merely provides for the funding of such expenditures from Loan Fund to the extent that moneys of the CRF are insufficient.

The Parliament passed the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 in the Budget sittings authorising the charging of defence expenditure up to $1500 million to the Loan Fund. In introducing the legislation into the Senate in October last year, the former Minister for Finance indicated that prospective expenditures looked like exceeding the budget by some $750 million. Since that time revised estimates of receipts and outlays have indicated a prospective deficit of the order of $4.5 billion, nearly $3 billion in excess of the budgeted deficit of $1.7 billion and substantially higher than that in prospect in October 1982.

These revisions to the Estimates reflect of course on the Government's funding arrangements and it has become necessary to seek supplementation of the authority under the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 to charge CRF expenditures to Loan Fund.
To achieve this purpose the Bill proposes:
First, that the authority under the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 to charge defence expenditures to Loan Fund be increased by $1200 million; and

Secondly, as defence expenditures may not be charged to Loan Fund retrospectively, that authority be provided to reimburse CRF from Loan Fund in respect of other expenditures up to the limit of the Commonwealth's Loan Council borrowing program.

I consider these additional authorisations provide an adequate margin to enable the Government to meet the prospective deficit in the CRF. However, the margin sought is contingent on the urgent passage of the Bill since, as I have previously stated, defence expenditure cannot be charged retrospectively to Loan Fund.

Finally I would re-emphasise that this measure does not of itself authorise additional expenditures over and above what the Parliament has already approved: it merely provides the mechanisms for the financing of such expenditures.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
