I present Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83 which, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982-83 which I shall present shortly, comprises certain urgent appropriation measures which cannot reasonably await the passage of the Additional Estimates in the main autumn sittings.

The need for these measures arises out of abnormally large calls on the contingency provisions-the advances to the Minister for Finance-contained in the Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83. The Government was advised immediately on coming to office that, on the basis of information then available, urgent expenditures not foreseen at the time of the Budget, could be expected to exceed the amounts available in the advances by early May with further substantial calls on them by the end of that month; this initial expectation has been reinforced by subsequent monitoring of the situation.
There is an urgent need to seek interim appropriation measures before the passage of the additional Estimates in the usual way in the main Autumn sittings .
The additional amounts sought in these interim appropriations total $407.3m, $ 211.3m in Appropriation Bill No. 3 and $196.0m in Appropriation Bill No. 4.

The principal factors underlying the abnormally large calls on the contingency provisions include post-Budget initiatives of the previous Government arising, inter alia, out of a fall in economic activity; the costs of the general election; drought and other natural disaster relief and associated costs; and higher than expected cost increases in some areas such as electricity charges.

While the additional appropriations sought in this Bill, and those that will be the subject of the normal additional estimates in the main sittings, have been partly offset by savings in appropriations made by the Appropriation Acts Nos (1 and 2) 1982-83, they nevertheless reflect the more general pressures that have led to the substantial blow-out in the Budget deficit. A statement of such savings will, as is usual, be provided to the Senate at the time of the Additional Estimates.

In seeking these interim appropriations the Government has had uppermost in mind two important matters of parliamentary principle: Firstly, the right of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys for specific purposes subject to accepted principles relating to the contingency provisions under the Advances to the Minister for Finance; second, the need to minimise the effects of not being able to avail ourselves of the normal processes for the scrutiny of estimates of expenditure.

The provisions sought in the Bills have therefore been carefully chosen with a view to minimising the amount of supplementation for the contingency advances while avoiding matters which the Parliament might reasonably expect to scrutinise more closely.

The major considerations in their selection have been that, with the exception of some bushfire relief payments recently agreed between the Prime Minister and the Premiers of Victoria and South Australia-provision for which has been included in the Appropriation Bill No. 4-they do not involve initiatives of the new Government; they are non-contentious; the expenditures are urgent and would normally be appropriate for the issue of funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance; and the amounts, or significant proportions of them, would but for the specific appropriations involve substantial demands on the advances before the end of May.

No specific provisions have been included for departmental salaries notwithstanding that, as a result of post-Budget decisions of the previous Government to substantially increase staff ceilings in the Social Security Department, the Taxation Office, and other areas, there could be significant calls on the advance contained in Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1982-83 before the passage of the Additional Estimates.

Of the additional $211.3m sought in this Bill, $50m is for supplementation of the Advance to the Minister for Finance contained in Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1982-83, reflecting estimates of urgent funds requirements before the end of May -by which time it is hoped the Additional Estimates will have been passed- together with a margin for further urgent and unforeseen requirements. All the prospective calls on the advance were, of course, unforeseen at the time the previous Government brought down its Budget.
The earlier the passage of the Additional Estimates, the lesser the likely calls on the Advance. However it is important that the supplementary provision is adequate to meet contingencies.

The specific appropriations include amounts for legal aid resulting from increased costs and unforeseen costs associated with the newly operating Victorian Legal Aid Commission; higher costs, especially electricity charges, associated with certain defence operations; higher rates of eligibility and increased average benefits under student assistance programs; additional places made available under the special apprentice training schemes; emergency relief for Lebanon; payments to meet higher operational losses sustained by the Australian National Railways Commission reflecting reduced cash flow as a result of the drought affected harvest and the economic downturn; and the costs of the general election itself.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: From the Opposition's point of view it seems timely to make the point that there has not been an opportunity for discussion of many of the matters that would require parliamentary discussion at the first stage of the parliamentary sitting of a new government. Comments were made this morning by Senator Grimes and other honourable senators that we had not raised matters of national importance with regard to the economy or decisions that were taken last week at the National Economic Summit Conference. It is the appropriate time here to suggest that that opportunity has not been given to the Australian Parliament.

The one-day sitting was originally designed for the introduction of these essential Appropriation Bills. The Opposition wishes to make the point that while it supports the passage of the Bills it finds it necessary to condemn the failure of the Government to provide an adequate and timely opportunity for the Senate to debate national issues relating to the National Economic Summit Conference which was held in Canberra last week. It is in those words that I will move an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. From the point of view of timing it seems to me to be appropriate that many of the matters that were discussed at the National Economic Summit Conference could have been and should have been discussed in parliamentary session because there are now the questions of the outcome of the Summit Conference, the communique that was issued from that meeting and what seems to be daily headlines that there has been some breakdown of the communique and the prices and incomes policy which had been endorsed at the Summit Conference. I would have thought that headlines that indicate, day after day, that the Summit wages pact has cracked or that there are obstacles to restraint, along with statements made by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions with regard to his understanding of what are the proper claims of unions under the accords and what seem to be other understandings of the same things, should have been discussed in parliamentary session so that if we were to be addressing some fact that there was an accord or that there was to be consensus about certain matters we would at least understand what was involved. It seems that the statements by the President of the ACTU this week that the promises of restraint by the unions under the prices and incomes accord would break down if the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission awarded less than full indexation under a new centralised system should be adequately discussed in the Parliament. A full understanding of what is involved in that accord should be developed.

I think it was further reported this week in interviews and discussions by the President of the ACTU that sectional wage increases would be a fact of life under a centralised wage fixing system. That comment was made despite the ACTU's commitment in the Summit to suppress sectional claims in a return to a centralised wage-fixing system. Sectional interests form part of the communique. There is the rider to that sectional interest claim that makes exceptions of special circumstances that are proved before a wage fixing authority. If we were to talk about special circumstances and exemptions from what had been given to be an understanding that sectional claims were to be suppressed, then I think it would be appropriate that this should be developed and that under discussion we would have some precision as to what is meant by the suppression of sectional claims and which sectional claims could be regarded as having special circumstances surrounding them.

The President of the ACTU and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) were both critical of the building unions' campaign several days ago. Yet in the intervening period we have now had other statements from the President of the ACTU. I think I would like to hear what the Prime Minister would say about matters such as sectional interests and the central wage fixing authority's responsibility to induce this compact and this consensus which have been spoken about so freely. I think we would also like to know what would be the Government's approach to the Arbitration Commission at the time that submissions were being made for its approval. These are the matters that we think should have had a great deal of parliamentary clarification and discussion.

In talking about the particular unions which are causing this confusion and distress with regard to the consensus, it seems to me strange that the Prime Minister can make statements that the housing industry will be used for the recovery of our economy when, indeed, the building unions at present are in a state of industrial chaos. I think this certainly warrants the headlines of a breakdown in the Summit Conference accord and the prices and incomes agreement between the unions and the Government. These are the matters that I would have liked to have had some time to discuss. I know there are other matters which my colleagues would like to raise as this is the first sitting of the Parliament in the period of the new Government.

At this time I confine myself to those introductory remarks on these Appropriation Bills and give the assurance that the Opposition does not wish to impede their passage. TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have seen today why it is that the remnants of this once noble political party, the Liberal Party, have been quite properly placed on the Opposition benches by the electorate. Whilst there was a time in its early ethos when the Liberal Party had something to contribute to the political culture of this nation, it is now quite clear why it will be consigned to the scrap heap of history. We have heard nothing today which gives any indication of an alternative vision, a goal for Australia, which the Liberal Party might propound to the Australian people or any indication of how it may wish to achieve that goal. The Governor-General said in this very chamber yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that the gravity of Australia's present crisis imposes on this Parliament a burden and a responsibility as challenging as that faced by any of its predecessors since Federation.

Whilst the Governor-General, the Queen's representative, outlined in this chamber yesterday a most comprehensive response and the taking-up of that challenge by the Australian Labor Party, we on this side of the chamber have been astonished over the last two days to find nothing emanating from the Opposition benches as to the Opposition's response to this great challenge. No hint, no glimpse of an alternative vision, has been offered by the Opposition parties. Indeed, on this first working day of the Parliament we have been rather obsessed with an issue to do with the propriety of using the Government's own aircraft to gather evidence for a case before the high Court.

It is not surprising that the Liberal Party is so bereft of ideas to place before the Australian people. After all, it ruthlessly conquered the political process in 1975 by degrading all the conventions of parliamentary democracy. It is ironic and fitting that its members now sit on the Opposition benches. It spawned the recent election, which brought about its defeat, by constitutional impropriety, by the former Prime Minister-let us not forget this-going to the Governor-General and seeking an election, misleading and deceiving the Governor- General as to the purpose of the election, saying: 'I need an election in order to get sales tax Bills passed because the Senate has refused to pass them'. Indeed, within a few days of having secured the election the Prime Minister said : 'Well really, that was only a sort of technicality; it was needed only in order to pull the wool over Sir Ninian Stephen's eyes'. That is the sort of political, constitutional impropriety which spawned the election which now sees the Liberal Party on the Opposition benches.

Let us not forget another aspect of that calling of the election. It was so early, so improper, so untimely in its calling that the electoral rolls were closed in a way which disenfranchised hundreds of thousands of our fellow Australians, particularly the young who have borne the most dramatic impact of the lack of policies and lack of vision of the previous Government and, of course, many Australians who took up their citizenship in this country and wanted to participate for the first time by voting in that parliamentary election. Once again the personality, the very character of the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, came through in his calling of that early, untimely election in such a way as to disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of our fellow Australians. Of course, there is one good effect of that early, untimely calling of the election; namely, that there is a strong sentiment within the Australian community in favour of constitutional reform, in favour of fixed term parliaments in order that a parliament may see through the business which is committed to it by the Australian people in any one election and so that we do not have the cynical opportunism which has characterised Australian political life so much in the last seven years.

My real complaint and the real point I am making is that nowhere in these early days of the meeting of this Parliament have we heard anything from the Opposition benches of the Opposition's vision for Australia. But, as I have said , perhaps it is not surprising that the cupboard is bare.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not heard anything from the Governor-General's Speech either about the vision for Australia.

—The Governor-General, on behalf of the Government, put forward a very comprehensive and detailed program to realise our vision for Australia, a vision of reconciliation and reconstruction which was endorsed overwhelmingly by the mass of the Australian people. Let honourable senators not forget that. Only in the dying hours of this afternoon's sitting did a senior Minister in the former Government get up and talk about a substantive issue, namely, the holding of the National Economic Summit Conference. The only point that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle seemed to wish to make was that further parliamentary discussion and elaboration of those proceedings would be appropriate. With that I agree. Indeed, that was the understanding of those who participated in that Conference. In the second last paragraph of the communique agreed to by that Conference it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Participants express their satisfaction at the degree to which these objectives have been met. The participants express the hope that this is the beginning of consensus, not the end. They understand the enourmous amount of detailed work that still remains to be done but express the hope that this work will be concluded as satisfactorily as this week's deliberations and with equal despatch .

Indeed, that is the hope of those on this side of the chamber. The electorate must be thoroughly bemused at the sight of the Opposition rendered so irrelevant so quickly to the processes of public policy-making in this community. The Opposition treated with derision and scorn the whole concept of the calling of the National Economic Summit. It stood by while a better understanding, a more soundly based foundation for our economic and social recovery, was forged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Until we found out that you broke your promises.

—There are interjections from the other side. The Sydney Morning Herald did not speak of the National Economic Summit Conference in the carping, strident, derisive tones of the Opposition. It is not a radical newspaper and it said that the Conference:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . represents the most daring, innovative, exciting experiment in Australia's political process and economic management since the War.
I presume that it was referring to World War II. It continued:
If it succeeds, it will lay the ground for a period of relative political harmony, and of progress in solving the economic problems which bedevil us.

TALK.START.PARA: —And if it fails?

—If it fails? But it did not fail. It has been an outstanding success. That has been acknowledged by every mature political commentator-not by the puny, irrelevant voices of the Opposition but by every experienced observer of the Australian political scene-and certainly by the mass of the Australian electorate, as revealed in the opinion polls which have shown the Australian Labor Party increasing the satisfactory ratings which it had in the electorate on 5 March. Now we find that the Liberal Party had nothing to offer whilst the great forces which control and determine the trading and commercial life of our nation-the representatives of capital and labour-have come together with government and achieved such remarkable consensus, a consensus which will help modify the struggle between capital and labour for their respective shares of restored growth in the economy. They have modified their claims in recognition of their common interests and those of the broader community.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, the Whips have asked us to be short in our remarks but I had hoped to comment on some of the issues that were raised during the last day or two in relation to South West Tasmania. With the indulgence of the Senate I will just make two or three short points. The Hawke Labor Government has been pursuing in this instance in a concrete, definite way, the theme of reconciliation which characterised its whole appeal to the Australian electorate on 5 March. I need only to remind all those on the other side who have spoken on the matter that, as I am sure the Australian electors remember, on the night of the election victory-indeed, at the very moment of claiming that victory-the Prime Minister elect, Mr Hawke, offered to the Tasmanian people his firm assurance that nothing would be done in relation to Tasmania which would be in any sense discriminatory or which would have any deleterious impact on the community of Tasmanians who voted against the Australian Labor Party in that Federal election. That note of reconciliation has permeated all the correspondence and all the attempted negotiations with the Premier since that date.

Reconciliation does not mean a complete submerging or obliterating of claims, but it does mean recognising facts, including new facts. A new fact which has emerged over the last month, of course, is the election of the Australian Labor Party to government in this country. As the Governor-General himself noted in his Speech, there is a very clear mandate in regard to this matter. Mr Gray chooses to ignore that new fact. But, more importantly, as I have said, reconciliation is achieved not by giving up one's concerns but by recognising a larger common objective. Indeed, I believe this is what was offered by Mr Hawke in his recognition that the common objective of Tasmanians and Australians relating to this issue is the provision of adequate energy supplies for Tasmania 's future and adequate employment opportunities for those who might have expected employment, whether they be Hydro-Electric Commission employees or independent contractors, on this project. Once that common objective was recognised, I believe there were grounds for reconciliation, negotiation and consultation but they were not taken up by the Premier. Indeed, the Premier threatened in various ways which one does not have time to detail. He even threatened to arrest Australian Federal Police should they enter that area.

Finally, under the constraints of time in relation to this matter I would simply say that now that the matter is in the High Court one sees the true constitutional propriety of this Government. It is not this Government which will determine whether it is constitutionally proper to attempt to halt construction of the Franklin project. It is the bench of High Court justices who will interpret the Constitution and apply it to this situation. We stand ready to abide by the Court's decision. We are acting constitutionally in exactly the proper way, in the way in which one would expect, and in the way which will characterise the term of office of this Government. It is true that we are part of an indissoluble Federal Commonwealth and the federal nature of that union needs to be recognised. But I also say that it is indissoluble and any hysterical talk of secession ought not to be heard in this chamber.

No doubt there will be an opportunity when Bills are introduced to elaborate more fully on these matters. But I would hope that in the month of May at least we might see a fuller expression if it is possible-if honourable senators opposite are not totally bereft of ideas-of the competing philosophy of the Opposition parties as we try to achieve the mandate given to us by the Governor- General yesterday, namely, to use this parliamentary forum to achieve some sort of reconciliation and growth within Australia which can provide a basis for our future prosperity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the very limited opportunity that I have this afternoon to speak in support of the amendment moved by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The amendment has been moved to draw attention to the fact that, whilst this new Government has seen fit to bring together the Parliament and the people who make it up, it has not seen fit to make any provision whatsoever for an opportunity to debate the matters which it thought were of such moment that it drew together the summiteers to Canberra for the whole of last week. Yet, even with the opportunity to have everybody in Canberra to discuss these matters of moment through the elected representatives, the Government has chosen to close down the Parliament and to prevent us from having the opportunity of debating these matters. So, I warmly support adding to the motion for the second reading the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate, whilst supporting the passage of this Bill, condemns the failure of the Government to provide an adequate and timely opportunity for the Senate to debate national issues related to the National Economic Summit Conference held in Canberra last week.

I would like to refer to some of the issues. They include the failure of this Government in the sense that promise and performance are already the stigmas which attach to this new Government that has been in office for such a short time. It is already finding excuse after excuse for failing to do or failing to be able to promise to do any of the things which it said it would do at the time when it conned the people of Australia into voting for it. One of the massive confidence tricks of all time was the election campaign which was followed by the absolute confidence trick of all time-the Summit Conference. At that Conference big business was conned into joining in an agreement which had already been made between big government and big unions. The Government conned big business into joining them without regard to the interests of the rest of Australia which is the vast majority of Australian people who were excluded from the Conference and from the agreement, and whose interests are not protected in any way whatsoever.

Let me refer to what the unions have been doing while this confidence trick has been taking place. Tasmania was held to ransom, as usual, by shipping unions which did not want to operate the ships. It did not suit them to let ships service Tasmania as they are supposed to do. The great conciliator, the man who we find is at the head of the confidence trick called the Labor Government, was doing nothing about getting the ships operating to Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will see how you do in Billy Snedden's seat.

—Senator Tate was not concerned about getting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to do something to get those Australian National Line ships back to work. Those ships were banned by his mates in that union who spend more time shooting each other but who sometimes spend a bit of time on industrial disputation as well. Let me go on to talk about what the builders labourers have been doing. Twenty separate bans are operating and have been in operation for anything up to 12 months and they are still going on. The great conciliator, the man who is going to bring Australia together, has done not a thing about this matter. He has not even mentioned it. He has done nothing except bring our erstwhile refugee from Pentridge Gaol to sit in the Parliament.
—Come on, that's crook. You know it. He got out rightfully. There is nothing extraordinary in that and you know it.

—It was extraordinary to have him sitting in our Parliament when he has not been elected any more than the other people who were sitting in this Parliament. Let me go on to refer to some other matters in the very limited time I have available to me because, by agreement, we are to speak for ten minutes only at a time when there are so many matters which need to be referred to. Twenty separate bans have been imposed on projects which would provide employment and generation of economic activity around Australia. What is happening in relation to all of these projects? Nothing is happening because of bans imposed by the Builders Labourers Federation. Let us have a look at the, I think, $150m project in the Hunter Valley which has been severely hit by unemployment and by the problems of the steel industry. What is happening in relation to that project? It is sitting there. The investment has been made; the trucks are there; and everybody is waiting for someone-perhaps the great conciliator-to sort out what will happen in relation to that project. What about the bans that have been imposed by the vehicle builders in the troubled vehicle industry? Why is not somebody doing something about lifting those bans? What about the Garden Island Dockyard stoppage? In a troubled industry which has an employment problem, the workers have gone on a sympathy strike causing the loss of 325 hours as a mark of respect for one of their former members.
—What about the drought? Don't forget the drought.

—I have to concede that the honourable senator has me. The great conciliator came to terms with the Almighty and broke the drought. I could not do other than recognise that after the great conciliator took over the reins of Australia the rains did come. Let us go back to the real world. The meat workers in Queensland are happily imposing bans which are going on for week after week in an industry where real people are troubled about employment opportunities and about the drought to which Senator Tate has just referred. But they are being held back in their opportunities to be able to overcome the problems which have been created by the drought as a result of industrial bans about which the great conciliator, our new Prime Minister, does nothing. He does nothing while he struts around holding the greatest confidence trick Australia has yet witnessed-the Summit. Let me go on. I refer to the failure of the Government to enable many interested individuals and groups within the community to express a view and to be heard. Let us see who was at this great Summit. Unfortunately I have so much material which I would like to incorporate. If somebody would like to move that I incorporate it, I would be happy to. The government participants-big government-were 29, big business were 35 and big unions were 25. That is a total of 89 out 100 participants. That hardly reflects the real distribution of the balance of interests in this community. How were the millions of smaller people represented? They were represented by only one organisation, the Australian Council of Social Service. Where were the representatives of the millions of people who, as Senator Grimes would well know , have the real problems and who are really disadvantaged at the moment? Big unions are not suffering a real disadvantage; big business is not suffering a real disadvantage; and big government is just luxuriating itself. The people who came to this Summit were treated to white cars at their beck and call and to wining and dining in order to buy them. What a price for them to pay. It was beyond belief that those people were prepared to join in that communique for the sake of a couple of bottles of wine and rides in a couple of white cars. Out of the 100 people who were there, excluding observers, 89 of them clearly represented big business, big government and big unions. Of the others, there were five who questionably represented the smaller sections of business, three represented professional groups and only three out of 100 represented some of the other organisations of the community, which were not given the opportunity to participate.

SPEECH.PARA: The invitations were so arranged that the interests were those only of big business, big government and big unions. Central wage fixing, with all of its implications, did not receive an opportunity for real consideration but was made part of the terms of the confidence trick which was put over Australians. There was no real effort to approach the question of real job creation. There was a failure to devise machinery for achieving restraint. There was a failure to give science and technology an appropriate priority. Mr Jones, the Minister for Science and Technology, made that so obvious in his very vocal complaints about the fact that the real sunrise area of Australian industry was excluded from consideration in this great Summit Conference. That gives some idea of the reality, of the genuine nature or otherwise of the approach to this whole thing.

The failure to give appropriate priority and consideration to the tourism industry and its capacity for job creation, the failure to reach agreement or consensus on the importance of a return to more performance value-related wage rates for young Australians and to thereby increase their job opportunities, the failure to identify and reach agreement or consensus in relation to the actual methods for attaining national economic goals and the failure of the Government to place before the Summit proposals for the implementation of the election promises made by the Government, including tax cuts, are all matters in relation to which I suggest that not only the Parliament and the Summit but also the people of Australia were conned by the greatest confidence trick, by the great conciliator who failed dismally to get down to the sort of conciliation that this country really needs to overcome the sorts of problems that it is experiencing and to get back to work.

I regret that today will not provide an opportunity to debate this matter further, but as soon as we are allowed to, as soon as this Government will give us the opportunity, we will debate this matter at length as well as put forward proposals as to how we believe we ought to see Australia go about overcoming the problems which it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to move an additional amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982-83 after this amendment has been dealt with. I also, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, intend to move an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83. I would therefore like to reserve my right to speak on the main question and address myself at this stage only to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's amendment, which she has technically moved on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am tempted, as I have been on listening to Senator Rae's speech, to indulge in an adult version of the Kindergarten of the Air. I would restrict my comments to say only that if the Liberal-National Party coalition Opposition is so concerned about debating some of the matters of national importance, which it says were raised at the National Economic Summit Conference, I wonder why it wasted something like two hours this morning debating whether a Royal Australian Air Force aircraft should or should not have flown over Australian territory. Perhaps it may well be important in the eyes of Opposition senators but one wonders, given the impassioned speech just issued to this chamber by Senator Rae , why the Opposition puts that at a higher priority than the National Summit. I certainly agree with Senator Rae that it fell short in a certain number of respects, not the least of which were that in this chamber not one representative of a women's group was there in a speaking capacity. Certainly there were one or two as observers, but to the best of my knowledge the only female presence on the floor was in the person of Senator Susan Ryan who is certainly capable but she was there in her capacity as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs rather than spokesperson for any particular women's groups. So the Liberal-National Party Opposition and the Democrats were not the only groups representing significant portions of Australian society which were not represented at that Summit.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's amendment does two things: It indicates that it supports the passage of the Bill-that is Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982-83, and presumably also Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83 and the Loan Bill 1983. It then goes on to indicate censure of the Government for not giving the Senate time to debate those issues of national importance which were raised at the Economic Summit just past. It is this reference of condemnation, this censure motion, which results in the Australian Democrats not supporting the Opposition amendment. Certainly we have some sympathy for the contents of the motion, but it has been our practice in the past not to support motions which censure the Government unless there is some absolutely reprehensible action behind it. As an example I refer to a censure motion that was moved by the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button, against the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, on 9 April 1981. At that time senators of the Australian Democrats opposed that censure motion, and we will oppose this one.

This Parliament has sat for two days after a delay of five months, which was entirely due to the fact that the last Government's election whims caused the Parliament to be dissolved. It is simply not good enough then for that ex- government to come in here and complain that after two days debate has not been undertaken on matters of the economic direction this country is going to take in the next couple of years. That is hardly a reprehensible situation. I think even the Labor Government is entitled to something more than two days before it is censured from this side of the House. The Democrats would certainly like to see some debate on economic matters before the end of May particularly those raised at the Summit. I trust that the Labor Government will oblige us and the rest of the Opposition in that. For that reason it is not our intention to support Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982- 83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not speak at great lenght but I think I should reply to some of the points which have been made, in particular, to the carping criticism of last week's Summit Conference from members of the Opposition. I suppose one could say that members of the Opposition are entitled to be petulant as a result of the Summit Conference because they were completely excluded, left way out in the cold, in isolation and were placed in the wilderness where, if today's performance is any indication, they are destined to remain for a very long time. It is really displaying too much chutzpah for them to move the amendment which they have.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment is plainly humbug for two reasons. Firstly, if the Opposition wanted an opportunity to debate economic matters it had an opportunity to raise a matter of public importance this morning. The time could have been devoted to a debate on economic matters. Instead honourable senators opposite decided to waste time on a tedious and trivial discussion about the recent activities of a couple of Royal Australian Air Force planes. I stress that this came from the same people who were silent when their Government used the Royal Australian Air Force for exactly the same reason-to photograph Fraser Island a few years ago. The people who engineered the situation of urgency under which these Bills must be passed now have the chutzpah, or cheek if Senator Haines prefers that word, to complain about the Bills being passed in haste.
That brings me to the second reason why the Opposition's amendment is humbug. These Bills must be passed urgently for the simple reason that-

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not holding them up.

—The honourable senator is complaining about not having adequate opportunity for a debate. This sitting was called as a one-day sitting to pass urgent legislation. Two and a half months ago those who now sit opposite, with characteristically unbridled opportunism, decided to pull a premature election which they thought, mistakenly, they could win. As a result these Bills, which ought to have been introduced in the normal course of events in the Parliament at least one month ago, are now being debated. Because of the premature election that procedure could not be followed. It has become essential that these Bills be passed today. Originally that was intended to be done in a one-day sitting, but that was extended because the Opposition clearly wanted to discuss some other matters. It was extended to a two-day sitting. After wasting all morning debating a silly, trivial and tedious matter about an Australian aircraft flying over Australian territory, honourable senators opposite now have the audacity to complain that they do not have an opportunity in this short sitting of Parliament to have a proper debate on economic questions.

SPEECH.PARA: It requires a good deal more than the ordinary amount of cheek for any member of the former Government to complain about anybody else's economic management. The former Government was elected 7 1/2 years ago on a promise to beat inflation , reduce taxes and provide jobs for all. Seven years later inflation, which, when it took over, was at 13 per cent and on the way down, stood at 11 per cent and going up; taxation stood at all time record levels; and in the seven years that it was in office unemployment trebled. The former Government went out of government in disgrace, with an unemployment level above the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and inflation at almost double the OECD average. That was the end result of seven years of coalition government. In the second day of the parliamentary sitting of the new Government this discredited former regime has the audacity to suggest that the present Government should in some way be censured for the condition of the Australian economy.

The speech that Senator Peter Rae gave was really unworthy of a senator of his calibre. He was annoyed apparently by Mr Gallagher's presence at the Summit. I am not certain whether he objected to Mr Gallagher being present or to the fact that some other people who could be classified in a similar way, at least in one respect-such as Harry Miller-were not invited. The Opposition claims that it wants a debate on economic questions, but insofar as the honourable senator touched on economic questions at all, he had nothing constructive to contribute to an economic debate. I have already indicated that the Government will not accept the official Opposition's absolutely unjustified amendment. We accept the Australian Democrats' amendment which states that after these Bills have been passed-clearly they will be passed-the explanatory notes be referred to the appropriate Estimates committee for examination. I would have been quite happy to incorporate that amendment in the second reading motion which I have moved. I am equally happy, on behalf of the Government, to accept it as an amendment to the second reading motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter this debate, but I feel constrained to do so for two reasons. First of all, and most importantly, I believe it is important for us to put at rest this suggestion that what was brought forward today as a matter of public importance by the Opposition was one of insignificance. By definition it was no such thing. The question of the use of defence aid in support of the civil power is a matter which is crucial to democracy. If Senator Chipp or anybody else says that it is not they are not true democrats. Many a democratic country has been overthrown by the unauthorised use of defence aid in support of the civil power. That is one of the most fundamental and crucial questions that confront modern democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I am concerned about the fact that we have been dragged from every part of Australia to pass only three Bills and have not been given the opportunity to consider the vital issues which confront Australia internally. A large number of people-employers, unions and others in the community-were brought together last week to consider this matter for a whole week. I am not one of those who would suggest that that economic conference was just a public relations extravaganza. However, I believe that the functions and responsibilities of the national Parliament should not become too submerged into the operations and results of that Summit Conference and indeed in its ongoing suggested committee.

We should ensure that Australia is not governed by big business, big unions and big government. I do take issue with anyone who suggests that participants at the Conference thought that they were being a party to that. I have spoken to quite a number of them, both from the employers side and the unions side, who considered it their duty first of all to put aside a week to attend in Canberra and to put into their submissions the research and effort that so obviously went into their submissions. It was far from the minds of many of those who attended the Conference that they were trying to usurp the function and role of parliament.

Nevertheless, it was surely for the Government, once the Parliament met, to provide us with adequate opportunity to debate the issues which were raised at the Conference. This the Government has not done. It has not provided either the House of Representatives or the Senate with this opportunity. Instead, it has chosen in the House of Representatives to go on its mad hatter attack on Tasmania by introducing yet another Bill to attempt to override the properly made decision of the Tasmanian Parliament-not only the Tasmanian Government, the Tasmanian Parliament-by a vote of 51 of its 54 members. Both Labor and Liberal members supported the decision. We are not attempting to divert attention from the real economic issues that confront Australia, the twin evils of inflation and unemployment; it is the Government which is having its attention diverted from these twin evils. It was on the issue of unemployment and the fear of future unemployment that the Government was elected. It owes absolutely nothing to those who suggest that the issue was the Franklin Dam. What absolute nonsense . People are losing their balance and perspective over this issue. To give an example, on an Australian Broadcasting Commission program the leader of the push in Tasmania, Dr Bob Brown, said of the dams issue that it was possibly the greatest crisis this century. That is an example of the balance that has been lost in this debate. After all, we have had two world wars, the Great Depression , fires, floods and famines, yet Dr Brown is saying that this is possibly the greatest crisis this century. Some members of the Government are tagging along with that nonsense. If the Government looks at its vote in the election and compares the vote in the House of Representatives with the increased vote in the Senate it will find that it is very similar. The Government owes absolutely nothing to the so-called conservation groups. It certainly does not owe the fact that it gained government to them. It owes government to the fact that Malcolm Fraser was defeated on the unemployment issue. That is why I support the amendment moved by the Opposition expressing concern that we have not been given an adequate and timely opportunity to debate the national issues related to the National Economic Summit Conference held in Canberra last week. I fully support that amendment. I believe that it ought to be carried.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives has transmitted to the Senate the following message which has been distributed to honourable senators:

INTERJECT.PARA: Message No. 5 MR PRESIDENT,
The House of Representatives acquaints the Senate of the following Resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day:

The House of Representatives, recognizing the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:
(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention-

(a) a delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament take part in the deliberations of the Convention, and comprise sixteen members of the Parliament of whom six shall be members of the Senate and ten shall be members of the House of Representatives;

(b) the ten members of the House of Representatives comprise five members of the Australian Labor Party, three members of the Liberal Party of Australia and two members of the National Party of Australia.
(2) That-
(a) the Prime Minister and four other members of the House of Representatives, being members of the Australian Labor Party, nominated by him;
(b) the Leader of the Opposition and two other members of the House, being members of the Liberal Party of Australia, nominated by him; and
(c) two members of the House, being members of the National Party of Australia, nominated by the Leader of that Party,
be members of the Delegation.
(3) That the Prime Minister be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition be the Deputy Leader.
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if-
(a) he ceases to be a member of the Commonwealth Parliament;
(b) the House of the Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will increase the weekly rate of unemployment benefit for persons aged 18 or more who have no dependants. From 1 May 1983, the benefit will rise from $64.40 to $68.65 a week, so that those persons will be paid the additional amount of the automatic CPI increase which eligible pensioners and married beneficiaries will receive. The Government considers this an urgent priority because of the unwarranted cut in the living standards of the single adult unemployed since 1978. Between 1973 and 1978, the single adult unemployment benefit rate was the same as the rate for single pensioners and sickness beneficiaries.

In 1978, the previous Government froze this rate of benefit while continuing to index pension and sickness benefit rates. Since then, the pension has had eight automatic CPI adjustments while the single adult unemployment benefit has had only three minor ad hoc increases. The rate is now around 17 per cent below the standard rate of pension and sickness benefit and, without the May increase, would fall to some 22 per cent below the standard pension rate. it would also be less than half the rate payable to a married unemployed couple. It cannot be in dispute that the unemployed are the major victims of the economic downturn of the past few years. The demoralisation of the unemployed due to their jobless state has been compounded by the discrimination evident in the lower payments made to them by the previous Government.

During the election campaign, the Government committed itself to return to the pre-1978 position by progressively increasing the single adult unemployment benefit rate to the single pension rate. This Bill represents the first step towards achieving that goal. The cost of adjusting the unemployment benefit by this initiative is estimated at $15m for the remainder of this financial year, and $106m in 1983-84. The passage of this Bill will assist an estimated average of some 400,000 single adult beneficiaries this financial year and an estimated average of 480,000 in 1983-84. These totals include special beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries whose benefit rate is limited to the single rate of unemployment benefit.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Social Security Amendment Bill. The main reason that we support the legislation is that it adopts a measure which was foreshadowed in the former Government's policy speech on 15 September. It was agreed that we would propose upon election to upgrade the unemployment benefit by $4.25 a week in line with the September increase in the consumer price index. We on the Opposition side of the Senate are very pleased to recognise that once again, as in other areas, the new Government has adopted our policies. We hope that trend will continue as evidence of government recognition of the wisdom of following that course. For some years, while in Opposition, its supporters found it difficult to argue against following such a course but, having advanced their own alternatives, they have now found them difficult to implement.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other issues have arisen in recent times in connection with the payment of the unemployment benefit. The whole matter is, of course, one involving social security. Considerable confusion concerning future policies has been generated by the Government, since coming to office, in the minds of pensioners, superannuants, the unemployed and other welfare recipients. I note that even yesterday there was a specific reference, in the Governor-General's Speech, to a comprehensive review being undertaken of budgetary commitments in regard not only to outlays but, significantly, to taxation expenditures also. I recall that term being used by the famous Coombs committee during the period in office of the Whitlam Government, which adopted the approach of investigating so -called expenditures by way of a taxation system. By coincidence, there is in today's edition of the National Times a significant article on the subject attributed to Mr Geoff Kitney, who appears to have been very well backgrounded on Government policy generally in regard to this aspect. A great deal of attention is to be paid to it. In that context I would like to draw attention to the fact that, although I believe the Prime Minister (Mr Bob Hawke) stated only recently that there would be no change in regard to the taxing of superannuation payments, a very significant conclusion has been drawn by Mr Kitney which leads one to the conviction that this question is indeed wide open. That must be brought to the attention of the public as there has as yet been no clear indication from the Government as to its policy in this, or indeed in a number of other, areas. That is quite evident from the tone of the Governor-General's Speech.

Perhaps one should draw attention to one or two other points because, during the recent National Economic Summit Conference debate a great deal of attention was paid to the question of unemployment; great interest has been shown in it. Indeed, the Governor-General's Speech referred to job creation programs of one kind or another to combat unemployment. Reference was made to a specific road program, to be implemented in due course, presumably to employ young people. Those kinds of policies warrant close attention but when one considers the remarks of Ministers, especially in relation to their own little pet projects, one must feel some concern about whether the Government actually intends to carry out these programs. I draw to the attention of the Senate certain remarks attributed to the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones. As reported in an article in the Australian on 25 March, Mr Jones said that hopes of social security recipients could be dashed as the Federal Government strove to promote growth in the economy. He is reported to have said that increased social welfare payments could be swapped for more government funding of high technology industries as the Government looks to support silicon chip type industries, the big growth areas of the 1980s. I wonder whether that kind of thinking is to be applied by this Government in relation to programs such as it outlined in the Governor-General's Speech. I would like to know, and so would the people of Australia, what the Government's policy is in relation to welfare benefits. Did it not come to office on the promise that it would increase welfare benefits to the tune of $430m? Have we now not been conditioned to expect that those benefits will automatically accrue? What, for instance, has happened with regard to the promise of the Government in its election campaign to increase social security benefits for aged pensioners up to the full 25 per cent of average weekly earnings? The cost of that would be of the order of $11, 000m. Is the Government proposing to discard that promise?

We need answers to these questions because I think the Prime Minister skated over them all too glibly and, of course, has unsettled the public in a very significant way in recent times. In addition, there was, of course, the Prime Minister's promise in the election campaign to cut taxation by $630m. He said: ' I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election'. Not only has he snatched back the so-called fistful of dollars in relation to taxation but also it appears that superannuation and other welfare benefits are now at risk under this Government. We need more information from the Government as to its intentions rather than the broad statements which were incorporated in the Governor-General's Speech yesterday and which, of course, would be more unsettling than reassuring to that great mass of people who are dependent upon welfare benefits.

Those points will no doubt become matters for further debate in this place in the months ahead, but let it be said that the Opposition strongly supports this piece of legislation for the increase of benefits for unemployed people 18 years of age and over without dependants simply because it was part of our election platform and manifesto in recent times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment Bill amends the Social Security Act to increase the unemployment benefit for recipients aged 18 years of age and over without dependants from $64.40 per week to $68.65 per week as from 1 May. It pleases me to hear that the Opposition is supporting this legislation. I hoped that it would have supported it even if, as it says, it had not suggested it in the first place, and I trust that it will support in future similar increases in welfare payments to those people who are on the receiving end of some of the worst problems facing Australian society at the moment. I endorse fully the comments that the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) included in his second reading speech. I should like to raise only one other matter very briefly at this time; that is, that despite the fact that unemployment benefits for this group of people have been increased by some $4 they are still something like $20 below the latest poverty line figures supplied by the Melbourne Institute for Applied Economic and Social Research last November and are still $14 below that level if housing costs are excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: I can appreciate the fact that the record deficit this Government has inherited from the preceding Government is something of a hindrance in correcting a lot of the anomalies that exist in the social welfare system, but I nevertheless urge the Minister, while I have his ear, to look at removing this discrepancy between the poverty line and unemployment benefits for 18 year olds and over without dependants. These people have to eat, the same as everybody else, and they need to rent homes or purchase them if they can, the same as everybody else. They have the same sorts of expenses that most people have.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you prick them do they not bleed?

—Let us not get into that debate. I am not sure I can deal with Catholics quoting Shylock at this late stage of the debate. I will leave my remarks simply at that. The Australian Democrats support the measures contained in this Bill and request that the Minister turn his not unsympathetic attention to raising the payment still more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Opposition parties for their support of this legislation. In particular, I thank Senator Haines for confining her remarks to the subject matter of the legislation, unlike the speaker before her. Of course, Senator Haines's remarks about the level of the unemployment benefit for the single unemployed are valid. She knows as well as I do that the reason the single unemployed have reached the present parlous situation with regard to the unemployment benefit is that the previous Government chose in 1978 to deny them indexation of their benefit. I would have liked the Government to have been able immediately to increase the benefit to the standard rate of pensions and benefits in one hit but, as Senator Haines has pointed out, we were faced with a very large Budget deficit which we did not expect, which the Australian Democrats did not expect and which , I believe, most members of the Opposition parties did not expect either.
—You aren't very good at arithmetic if you didn't expect it. It was easy to work out. Your arithmetic is very poor.

—If it was easy to work out I wish that the honourable senator had let the populace know before the election campaign and maybe he and a few others would not be here now to annoy us. In any case it remains Australian Labour Party policy in the long term to increase the benefit to the standard rate of pensions and benefits. We hope to be able to do that in the full term of this Government. Clearly we cannot do it in one hit now. The stage at which we will be able to do it will depend on the State of the economy; we make no bones about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go into all the points made by Senator Messner at this stage. He mentioned Mr Barry Jones's speech, he mentioned taxation and he mentioned the Governor-General's Speech. In fact he mentioned everything except the legislation before us. The one thing he pointed out though, which is perfectly accurate, is that this move was in the Liberal Party policy speech and in Labor Party policy. But he did not mention that it was the only welfare promise in the whole of the Liberal Party policy speech. We have now completely fulfilled its platform. I assure honourable senators that in the next three years we will try to restore the state of pensions and benefits in this community to somewhere near their relative state in 1975 from which they have been allowed to deteriorate since. I thank the Senate again for the speedy passage of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
